20 October 2011: 1 | notes = }} The '''2010â2011 Greek protests''' are an ongoing series of demonstrations and [[general strikes]] taking place across Greece. The protests, which began on 5 May 2010, were sparked by plans to cut public spending and raise taxes as [[austerity measures]] in exchange for a {{Nowrap|â¬110 billion}} bail-out, aimed at solving the [[Greek financial crisis|2010â2011 Greek debt crisis]]. Three people were killed on the 5 May protests, one of the largest in Greece [[Athens Polytechnic Uprising|since 1973]]. Protest activity has escalated since then, leading to widespread [[social unrest]] and [[anti-government]] sentiment. On {{Start date|df=yes|25 May 2011}}, anti-austerity protestors organized by the [[Direct Democracy Now!]] movement, known as the '''Indignant Citizens Movement''' ({{lang-el|ÎÎ¯Î½Î·Î¼Î± ÎÎ³Î±Î½Î±ÎºÏÎ¹ÏÎ¼Î­Î½ÏÎ½ Î Î¿Î»Î¹ÏÏÎ½}}, ''KÃ­nima AganaktismÃ©non PolitÃ³n''), started demonstrating in major cities across Greece. This second wave of demonstrations proved different from the years before{{cite web |url=http://www.koutipandoras.gr/?p=7205 |title=ÎÎºÏÎ¿Î¼ÏÎ®: Î Î´ÏÏÎ¼Î¿Ï (Î³Î¹Î± ÏÎ·Î½ ÏÎ»Î±ÏÎµÎ¯Î±) ÎµÎ¯ÏÎµ ÏÎ·Î½ Î´Î¹ÎºÎ® ÏÎ¿Ï Î¹ÏÏÎ¿ÏÎ¯Î± |language=Greek |date=13 June 2011 |publisher=www.koutipandoras.gr |accessdate=7 July 2011}} in that they are not partisan{{cite web |url=http://www.skai.gr/news/greece/article/170468/oi-aganaktismenoi-diadilonoun-stis-ellinikes-poleis-/ |title=Î£ÏÎ± ÏÎ½Î¬ÏÎ¹Î± ÏÏÎ½ ÎÏÏÎ±Î½ÏÎ½ Î±Î³Î±Î½Î±ÎºÏÎ¹ÏÎ¼Î­Î½ÏÎ½ (On the footsteps of the Spanish 'indignados') |language=Greek |date=26 May 2011 |publisher=www.skai.gr |accessdate=26 May 2011}} and began through peaceful means.{{cite web |url=http://www.skai.gr/news/greece/article/170337/aganaktismenoi-sto-sudagma/ |title=ÎÎ³Î±Î½Î±ÎºÏÎ¹ÏÎ¼Î­Î½Î¿Î¹ ÏÏÎ¿ Î£ÏÎ½ÏÎ±Î³Î¼Î± |language=Greek |date=24 May 2011 |publisher=www.skai.gr |accessdate=7 July 2011}} Some of the protests later turned violent, particularly in the capital city of [[Athens]].{{cite web|url=http://www.metro.co.uk/news/866478-violent-anti-cut-riots-in-greece-spark-coalition-talks |title=Violent anti-cut riots in Greece spark coalition talks |publisher=Metro.co.uk |date=2011-06-15 |accessdate=2011-06-30}}{{cite web|url=http://www.usamarketnews.com/featured/3761/greece-anxiety-increases-us-stocks-ends-lower-on-wednesday-trading.html |title=Greece Anxiety Increases: US Stocks Ends Lower on Wednesday Trading Â« USA Market News |publisher=Usamarketnews.com |date=2011-06-16 |accessdate=2011-06-30}}{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-13787323 |title=BBC News - Greek PM George Papandreou to unveil new cabinet |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=2011-06-16 |accessdate=2011-06-30}}{{cite web|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/41734011/ns/world_news-europe/t/greek-riot-police-protesters-clash-during-crippling-strike/ |title=Greek riot police, protesters clash during strike - World news - Europe - msnbc.com |publisher=MSNBC |date=2011-02-23 |accessdate=2011-06-30}} Sparked by the [[2011 Spanish Protests]], these demonstrations were organized entirely using [[social networking sites]], which earned it the nickname "May of Facebook".{{cite web |url= http://www.ethnos.gr/article.asp?catid=11424&subid=2&pubid=63092999 |title=Î ÎÎ¬Î·Ï ÏÎ¿Ï Facebook ÎºÎ±Î¹ Î¼Îµ Î¿Î¼ÏÏÎ­Î»ÎµÏ |publisher=www.ethnos.gr |accessdate=27 May 2010}} The demonstrations and square sit-ins were officially ended when municipal police removed demonstrators from [[Thessaloniki]]'s [[White Tower]] square on 7 August 2011.{{cite web |url=http://www.protothema.gr/greece/article/?aid=138427 |title=ÎÏÎ¿Î¼Î±ÎºÏÏÎ½Î¸Î·ÎºÎ±Î½ Î¿Î¹ "ÎÎ³Î±Î½Î±ÎºÏÎ¹ÏÎ¼Î­Î½Î¿Î¹" Î±ÏÏ ÏÎ¿Î½ ÎÎµÏÎºÏ Î ÏÏÎ³Î¿ |publisher=www.protothema.gr |accessdate=9 August 2011}} On 29 June 2011, violent clashes occurred between the [[riot police]] and protesters as the Greek parliament voted to accept the EU's austerity requirements. Accusations of [[police brutality]] were reported by international media such as the [[BBC]], [[The Guardian]], [[CNN iReport]] and the [[New York Times]] as well as [[Amnesty International]].{{cite news |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-13960947 |title=Greece passes key austerity vote |publisher=www.bbc.co.uk |accessdate=29 June 2011 |date=29 June 2011}}{{cite news |publisher=www.amnesty.org |accessdate=30 June 2011}}{{cite news |url=http://ireport.cnn.com/docs/DOC-628589?ref=feeds%2Foncnn |title=Back when peaceful demonstrations in Greece were massive and Clashes in the Streets of Athens |publisher=www.nytimes.com |accessdate=3 July 2011 |first1=Rachel |last1=Donadio |first2=Scott |last2=Sayare |date=29 June 2011}} The Athens Prosecutor accepted pleas for an investigation in the case of excessive use of tear gas, as well as the alleged use of other expired and carcinogenic chemical substances, and the investigation is currently under way.{{cite web |url=http://www.skai.gr/news/greece/article/173682/paremvasi-tis-eisaggelias-protodikon-gia-ta-himika-sta-epeisodia/ |title=Î Î±ÏÎ­Î¼Î²Î±ÏÎ· ÏÎ·Ï ÎÎ¹ÏÎ±Î³Î³ÎµÎ»Î¯Î±Ï Î ÏÏÏÎ¿Î´Î¹ÎºÏÎ½ Î³Î¹Î± ÏÎ± ÏÎ·Î¼Î¹ÎºÎ¬ ÏÏÎ± ÎµÏÎµÎ¹ÏÏÎ´Î¹Î± |publisher=www.skai.gr |language=Greek |accessdate=30 June 2011}} ==Background of the 2010 protests== {{Greek economic crisis}} {{Further|[[Greek government debt crisis]]|[[Economy of Greece#2010 debt crisis|Economy of Greece > 2010-2011 debt crisis]]}} In the early-mid 2000s, Greece's economy was strong and the government took advantage by running a large deficit. As the world economy cooled in the late 2000s, Greece was hit especially hard because its main industriesâ[[Greek Merchant Navy|shipping]] and [[tourism in Greece|tourism]]âwere especially sensitive to changes in the business cycle. As a result, the country's debt began to pile up rapidly. In early 2010, as concerns about Greece's national debt grew, policy makers{{who|date=November 2011}} suggested that emergency bailouts might be necessary. On 5 March 2010, the [[Hellenic Parliament]] passed the cost-cutting Economy Protection Bill. On 23 April, the Greek government requested that a bailout package offered by the [[European Union]] and the [[International Monetary Fund]] be activated. The funds were expected to be available quickly, but it was unclear if they would be activated before a crucial 19 May debt rollover. On 27 April, [[Standard & Poor's]] cut the country's main debt rating to BB+ (considered "junk" status), increasing concern that a [[Default (finance)|default]] might occur.{{cite news|title= Cuts to Debt Rating Stir Anxiety in Europe |url= http://www.nytimes.com/2010/04/28/business/global/28drachma.html |work=The New York Times |author=Jack Ewing and Jack Healy |date=27 April 2010 |accessdate=6 May 2010}}{{cite news|url= http://www.theaustralian.com.au/business/markets/sp-downgrades-greek-debt-to-junk/story-e6frg91o-1225859110788 |title= S&P downgrades Greek debt to junk |author=Katie Martin and Terence Roth |publisher=Dow Jones Newswires |date=28 April 2010 |accessdate=6 May 2010}} ===Austerity measures=== On 1 May, Prime Minister [[George Papandreou (junior)|George Papandreou]] announced a fourth round of austerity measures by the Greek government, which have been described as "unprecedented".{{cite news|url= http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2010/may/09/greece-debt-crisis-euro-imf |title= The Greek spirit of resistance turns its guns on the IMF |author=Helena Smith |date=9 May 2010 |accessdate=10 May 2010 |work=The Guardian |location=UK }} These include more public sector pay cuts, pension reductions, new taxes on company profits, an increase on luxury and [[sin tax]]es, and an increase of the [[value added tax]], among others.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/8655711.stm|title=Greece police tear gas anti-austerity protesters|date=1 May 2010|publisher=BBC News }}{{cite web|url=http://www.in.gr/news/article.asp?lngEntityID=1132263&lngDtrID=251|title=Fourth raft of new measures|language=Greek|publisher=[[In.gr]] |date=2 May 2010 |accessdate=5 May 2010}} The proposed changes, which aim to save {{Nowrap|â¬30 billion}} through 2012, represent the biggest government overhaul in a generation. The cuts are in line with the EU-[[International Monetary Fund]] loan proposals which demand that Greece liberalise its economy and helped Greece reach a loan agreement, announced on 2 May, for an immediate {{Nowrap|â¬45 billion}} in loans (with a 5% interest for the major part, provided by the EU), with additional funds available in the future.{{cite web|title = Greece Accepts Terms of EU-Led Bailout, 'Savage' Cuts (Update2) â Bloomberg.com | url = http://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601087&sid=a9f8X9yDMcdI&pos=1 | publisher=[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]]|date=3 May 2010|accessdate=7 May 2010|author=Flavia Krause-Jackson and Gabi Thesing}}{{cite web|title = EU puts positive spin on Greek rescue|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/08a87e4e-55c4-11df-b835-00144feab49a.html|work=Financial Times|date=2 May 2010|accessdate=2 May 2010|first=Kerin|last=Hope}} The total value of the loans was expected to be in the {{Nowrap|â¬110 billion}} range. Papandreou submitted the bill to Parliament on 4 May. The Hellenic Parliament was expected to vote on the proposed austerity measures on 6 May. [[New Democracy (Greece)|New Democracy]], the conservative minority party, vowed to vote against the bill, but the bill was expected to pass due to the [[Panhellenic Socialist Movement]]'s large 160-seat advantage in Parliament. The government has pleaded with demoralized staff not to retire, fearing that a surge in benefits requests could further drain the public treasury. In separate votes on 29 June and 30 June, Parliament approved the austerity measures.{{cite news|url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-06-30/papandreou-wins-enough-votes-to-pass-greek-budget-bill-ensuring-bailout.html|title=Papandreou Wins Vote on Second Greek Austerity Bill in Bid for More EU Aid|last1=Weeks|first1=Natalie|last2=Bensasson|first2=Bensasson|work=[[Bloomberg News]]|date=2011-06-30|accessdate=2011-06-30}}{{cite news|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/06/30/greece-minister-eurogroup-idUSATH00622820110630|title=Greek finance minister welcomes austerity bill approval|last=Maltezeu|first=Renee|work=[[Reuters]]|date=2011-06-30|accessdate=2011-06-30}} ===Relationship to the 2008 Greek riots=== The [[2008 Greek riots]] started on 6 December 2008, when Alexandros Grigoropoulos ({{lang-el|ÎÎ»Î­Î¾Î±Î½Î´ÏÎ¿Ï ÎÏÎ·Î³Î¿ÏÏÏÎ¿ÏÎ»Î¿Ï}}), a 15-year-old student, was killed by two policemen{{cite news |url=http://www.ekathimerini.com/4dcgi/_w_articles_politics_100033_13/06/2009_108067|title=POLICE TRIAL Two indicted over teen shooting |publisher=Kathimerini}} in [[Exarcheia]] district of central [[Athens]]. While the unrest was triggered by the shooting incident, commentators{{cite news | url=http://edition.cnn.com/2008/WORLD/europe/12/08/explainer.greece.riots/index.html | title=Explainer: Why is there unrest in Greece? | publisher=CNN | date=10 December 2008 | accessdate=22 December 2008 }} described the reactions as expressing deeper causes as well, especially a widespread feeling of frustration in the younger generation about specific economic problems of the country (partly as a result of the [[economic crisis of 2008|global economic crisis]]), a rising unemployment rate among the young generation and a perception of general inefficiency and corruption in Greek state institutions.{{cite news | url=http://www.economist.com/world/europe/displaystory.cfm?story_id=12756043&fsrc=rss | title=Behind the protests spreading across Greece | publisher=Economist date=2008-12-09 | accessdate=12 December 2008 | date=9 December 2008}}{{cite news | url=http://www.iht.com/articles/2008/12/11/europe/greece.php | title=In Greece, a crisis decades in the making |work=International Herald Tribune | date=11 December 2008 | accessdate=12 December 2008 }} Related sporadic protests have continued into 2011. ==2010 protests== ===Before 5 May 2010=== {{Expand section|date=May 2010}} [[File:Greek protests austerity cuts May 2010.jpg|thumb|An arrest being made on May Day 2010.]] On May Day there were protest marches in [[Athens]] and [[Thessaloniki]], by many unions, left-wing, anarchist and communist party supporters. Violent clashes broke out when riot police were sent out to contain the protestors. On 4 May, members of the [[Communist Party of Greece]] broke into the [[Acropolis of Athens]] and hung banners urging the "Peoples of Europe [to] Rise Up".{{cite web|url=http://news.yahoo.com/s/ynews/ynews_wl1925|title=In Photos: Greek protesters storm the Acropolis|publisher=[[Yahoo! News]]|date=4 May 2010}} ===5 May 2010 strike and demonstrations=== In response to the proposed spending cuts and tax increases, a nation-wide strike was called for 5 May. Starting at midnight, airplane, train, and ferry traffic in and out of the country ceased. Schools, some hospitals, and many private businesses were closed. The demonstrations are seen by some as the most widespread since the end of the [[Greek military junta of 1967â1974]].{{cite news|title= Greek bailout: Athens burns â and crisis strikes at heart of the EU |url= http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2010/may/05/greek-bailout-economic-crisis-deaths |author=Helena Smith |work=The Guardian |location=UK |date=5 May 2010 |accessdate=7 May 2010 }} An estimated 100,000 people marched through Athens, with some estimates stretching to 500,000. As protests gained momentum, a large group tried to storm the parliament building in [[Syntagma Square]] in Athens, where they scuffled with police, causing some of the [[Evzones]] (ceremonial guards) to flee from the [[Tomb of the Unknown Soldier]]. The protesters accused members of parliament of being "thieves". Riot police were able to push the crowds back with [[tear gas]], [[flash bomb]]s and [[smoke bombs]]. Nearby buildings, including a finance ministry building, were set on fire. Prime Minister George Papandreou responded "Nobody has the right to violence and particularly violence that leads to murder. Violence breeds violence." [[File:Outside MARFIN bank.png|thumb|People paying their respects to the memory of the people who died on 5 May.]] [[image:May 2010 Greek protests.jpg|thumb|Demonstrators throwing objects at the riot police on 5 May 2010.]] Protesters set fire to a [[Marfin Investment Group|Marfin Bank]] branch on [[Stadiou Street]] with [[Molotov cocktails]]; witnesses said that protestors marching past the bank ignored the employees' cries for help, while others chanted [[anti-capitalist]] slogans. Most of the bank's employees managed to escape the burning building, but two employees who jumped from the second-story balcony were injured and two women and a man were found dead after the fire was extinguished. It was reported that fire crews had difficulty reaching the scene because of demonstrations moving through the area. The victims died of [[asphyxiation]] from toxic fumes when they were unable to escape from a roof exit that was blocked. They had gone to work despite the general strike over fears of losing their jobs.{{cite news| url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2010/may/09/greece-debt-crisis-euro-imf | location=London | work=The Guardian | title=The Greek spirit of resistance turns its guns on the IMF | first=Helena | last=Smith | date=9 May 2010}} They have been identified as Paraskevi Zoulia, 35, Angeliki Papathanasopoulou, 32 (who was four months pregnant) and Epaminondas Tsakalis, 36.{{Cite news|url=http://www.independent.co.uk/news/business/news/in-athens-the-day-was-calm-then-came-night-1965609.html |title=In Athens the day was calm. Then came night |work=The Independent |location=UK |date=7 May 2010 |accessdate=7 May 2010 | first1=John | last1=Lichfield | first2=Menelaos | last2=Tzafalias}} Papandreou called the incident a "murderous act". [[Michalis Chrysohoidis]], the [[Minister for the Protection of the Citizen]], declared that "today is a black day for democracy ... undemocratic forces have [latched on to] a peaceful demonstration of workers and now petrol bombs have killed three of our citizens and put an immediate danger to the lives of others." He also stated that "the killers will be caught and punished accordingly". Police started a widespread search, with the help of closed-circuit television footage in order to detect and arrest the suspects. The police blamed "hooded youth" for the incident, while one protestor who spoke to BBC blamed police brutality for the escalation of violence which was started when protestors threw [[Molotov cocktails]] at police; the police responded with pepper spray and tear gas. In response to the incident, the [[Greek Federation of Bank Employees' Unions]] blamed bank management for inadequate safety measures in the building and called for strike action. Elsewhere in Athens, some demonstrators threw rocks, bottles, and pieces of marble at the police. Numerous trash bins were lit on fire. Some broke windows, threw petrol bombs, and committed other acts of vandalism. Other protesters set up barricades and burned cars. Across Athens, at least 12 people were injured, and more than 70 people were detained for questioning.{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2010/WORLD/europe/05/05/greece.strikes/|title=Three dead as Greek strike grows violent|publisher=[[CNN International]]|accessdate=7 May 2010|date=2010-05-05|quote=and more than 70 were brought in for questioning by Wednesday evening | date=5 May 2010}} In [[Thessaloniki]], 37 people were arrested as a result of the protests. ====Aftermath of the 5 May protest==== On 5 and 6 May 2010, the Hellenic Parliament passed the proposed austerity measures, claiming they show the Greek government's commitment to tackling its [[budget deficit]], amongst continued protests.{{cite web|url=http://www.businessweek.com/news/2010-03-05/greek-protests-mount-as-parliament-passes-budget-cuts-correct-.html|title=Greek Protests Mount as Parliament Passes Budget Cuts (Update4)|publisher=[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]]|date=5 March 2010}}{{cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2010/05/07/world/europe/07greece.html|title=Greek Parliament Passes Austerity Measures|work=New York Times|date=5 May 2010|first=Dan|last=Bilersky}} Also on 5 May, the German parliament began debating the bailout package, as Chancellor [[Angela Merkel]] urged rapid passage. Merkel remarked that "Quite simply, Europe's future is at stake." The plan requires Germany to provide the largest share, {{Nowrap|â¬22 billion}}, of the bailout funds. The plan must be approved by 15 [[eurozone]] countries in total. Analysts said the protests could mark the beginning of protracted [[social unrest]]. If that occurs, the country could be pushed into deep recession. Economists have warned that it could be ten years before the Greek economy recovers, even if it does not worsen first. There has been advocacy for a [[political coalition]] from within the Greek political elite, and by the Greek journalist [[Alexis Papahelas]] who said that Papandreou should 'get rid of some of the novices he has in his government, make an overture to the opposition and go full-steam ahead.'{{cite web|url=http://www.ekathimerini.com/4dcgi/_w_articles_columns_100006_06/05/2010_116895|title=Which path will we take?|publisher=[[Kathimerini]]|first=Alexis|last=Papachelas}} One columnist at [[The Guardian]] suggests in an editorial that the protests speak of a deeper issue in Greek politics: she asks, 'What the advocates of this scenario [coalition government] do not seem to grasp is that the political class is out of touch with the population,' and 'How can we expect to see solutions and progress by the very same people who are inextricably, causally linked to the problem?'{{cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/commentisfree/2010/may/06/national-unity-greece-crisis|title=Greek debt crisis: coalition won't solve anything|work=The Guardian |location=UK |date=6 May 2010|first=Matina|last=Stevis }} ==Background of the 2011 protests== [[image:Greece public debt 1999-2010.svg|thumb|The first round of austerity in 2010 failed to stop Greece's rising debt, which is expected to go up by 10% in 2011.{{cite web|title=Î ÏÎ¿Î²Î»Î­ÏÎµÎ¹Ï ÏÎ·Ï ÎÏÏ. ÎÏÎ¹ÏÏÎ¿ÏÎ®Ï |url=http://www.tovima.gr/finance/article/?aid=400463 |publisher=To Vima |accessdate=3 July 2011}}]] {{Further|[[2010 European sovereign debt crisis#Greek government funding crisis|Greek Government funding crisis]]|[[Economy of Greece#2010 debt crisis|Economy of Greece > 2010-2011 debt crisis]]}} The memorandum signed between Greece and the IMF became largely unpopular in Greece, with some polls showing that 62% of the people asked believe it was a bad decision. This memorandum came into action October 7, 2011.{{cite web|title=MÎ½Î·Î¼ÏÎ½Î¹Î¿ Î­Î½Î± ÏÏÏÎ½Î¿ Î¼ÎµÏÎ¬: AÏÎ¿Î´Î¿ÎºÎ¹Î¼Î±ÏÎ¯Î±, Î±Î³Î±Î½Î¬ÎºÏÎ·ÏÎ·, Î±ÏÎ±Î¾Î¯ÏÏÎ·, Î±Î½Î±ÏÏÎ¬Î»ÎµÎ¹Î± |url=http://www.skai.gr/news/politics/article/169875/mnimonio-ena-hrono-meta-apodokimasia-aganaktisi-apaxiosi-anasfaleia/ |publisher=www.skai.gr |accessdate=18 May 2011 |date=29 May 2011}} Amid accusations that the government has not achieved its goals according to the IMF memorandum, some countries in the [[European Union]] have stated that they will not be lending Greece any more money if the IMF does not do so, including the Netherlands, Germany and Sweden.{{cite web|title=Î£ÎºÎ»Î·ÏÎ® Î³ÏÎ±Î¼Î¼Î® Î­Î½Î±Î½ÏÎ¹ ÏÎ·Ï ÎÎ¸Î®Î½Î±Ï Î±ÏÏ ÏÎ¿ÏÏ ÎÎ»Î»Î±Î½Î´Î¿ÏÏ |url=http://www.skai.gr/news/finance/article/170745/skliri-grammi-enadi-tis-athinas-apo-tous-ollandous-/ |publisher=www.skai.gr |accessdate=29 May 2011 |date=29 May 2011}}{{cite web|title=ÎÎ½Î­ÏÏÏÎ¿ ÎºÏÎ±ÏÎ¹ÎºÎ® ÏÎµÏÎ¹Î¿ÏÏÎ¯Î± Î¸Î­Î»Î¿ÏÎ½ ÎÎµÏÎ¼Î±Î½Î¯Î±, Î¦Î¹Î½Î»Î±Î½Î´Î¯Î± ÎºÎ±Î¹ ÎÎ»Î»Î±Î½Î´Î¯Î± |url=http://www.skai.gr/news/finance/article/170713/enehuro-kratiki-periousia-theloun-germania-finlandia-kai-ollandia-/ |publisher=www.skai.gr |accessdate=29 May 2011 |date=28 May 2011}} Some European officials went so far as to say that Greece should start selling away its assets to other European nations in order to receive loans, and the [[Dutch people|Dutch]] Minister of Finance said that the Greek parliament would not like this proposal and characterized the opinion of the Greek parliament as "a sensibility" that no one can consider at this time. Meanwhile, unemployment exceeded 15%, while a big percentage of full-time workers were only awarded the minimum wage of 592 Euros, or even less.{{cite web|title=Î¤Î·Î½ ÎµÎ»Î¬ÏÎ¹ÏÏÎ· Î±Î¼Î¿Î¹Î²Î® ÏÎ±Î¯ÏÎ½ÎµÎ¹ ÏÎ¿ 25% ÏÏÎ½ ÎµÏÎ³Î±Î¶Î¿Î¼Î­Î½ÏÎ½- ÎÎºÎ¬Î»ÏÏÏÎ¿Î¹ Î±ÏÏ ÏÎ¿ Î½ÏÎ¼Î¿ Î¿Î¹ Î¬Î½ÎµÏÎ³Î¿Î¹ |url=http://news.in.gr/economy/article/?aid=1231110553 |publisher=in.gr |accessdate=31 May 2011 |date=27 May 2011}}{{cite web|title=Î£ÏÎ¿ 15,9% Î· Î±Î½ÎµÏÎ³Î¯Î± ÏÎ¿ Î¦ÎµÎ²ÏÎ¿ÏÎ¬ÏÎ¹Î¿ |url=http://www.imerisia.gr/article.asp?catid=12336&subid=2&pubid=111171174 |publisher=www.imerisia.gr |accessdate=31 May 2011 |date=13 May 2011}} Rumours in regards to Greece's exclusion from the [[Eurozone]] also added to the mounting frustration, but these were categorically rejected by the Greek government, the [[European Central Bank]], the [[Bank of Greece]] and IMF-director nominee, and French Finance Minister, [[Christine Lagarde]].{{cite web|title=ÎÎ±Î³ÎºÎ¬ÏÎ½Ï: Î Î±Î»Î»Î·Î»ÎµÎ³Î³ÏÎ· Î±Î½ÏÎ¯ÏÏÎ¿Î¹ÏÎ· Î¼Îµ ÏÎ¹Ï ÎµÎ»Î»Î·Î½Î¹ÎºÎ­Ï ÏÏÎ¿ÏÏÎ¬Î¸ÎµÎ¹ÎµÏ |url=http://www.skai.gr/news/finance/article/170752/papadimos-i-katastasi-tis-oikonomias-epideinothike-/ |publisher=www.skai.gr |accessdate=29 May 2011 |date=29 May 2011}}{{cite web|title=Î ÏÎ¿Î²ÏÏÎ¿ÏÎ»Î¿Ï: Î Î±Î½ÏÎµÎ»ÏÏ Î³ÎµÎ»Î¿Î¯Î± ÏÎ± ÏÎµÏÎ¯ ÎµÎ¾ÏÎ´Î¿Ï Î±ÏÏ ÏÎ¿ ÎµÏÏÏ |url=http://www.skai.gr/news/finance/article/170661/provopoulos-padelos-geloia-ta-peri-exodou-apo-to-euro-/ |publisher=www.skai.gr |accessdate=29 May 2011 |date=27 May 2011}} On 29 June 2011, amid violent protests, the second austerity package was passed with 155 votes in favor in the 300-seat parliament. The next day, the Office of the [[High Commissioner for Human Rights]] of the [[United Nations]] reported an independent UN expert's warning that the austerity measures could result in violations of the Greek people's [[human rights]], such as "rights to food, water, adequate housing and work under fair and equitable conditions".{{cite web |url=http://www.un.org/apps/news/story.asp?NewsID=38901&Cr=austerity&Cr1= |title=Greek austerity measures could violate human rights, UN expert says |date=30 June 2011 |publisher=www.un.org |accessdate=3 July 2011}} Meanwhile, other international media have questioned the necessity of a second austerity package, when the first one brought in no results.{{cite news|title=Greece and austerity: Brussels v the people |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/commentisfree/2011/jun/29/greece-austerity-brussels-people?intcmp=239 |publisher=www.guardian.co.uk |accessdate=4 July 2011 |location=London |date=29 June 2011}} When Greece signed the Memorandum with the European Union and the IMF in 2010, the matter of the constitutional legality of the memorandum came under criticism in Greece, both by the people and some of the country's most prominent university professors of law.{{cite web|title=ÎÎ±Î¹ "ÎÏÎ¼Î±" ÎºÎ±ÏÎ¬ ÏÎ¿Ï ÎÎ½Î·Î¼Î¿Î½Î¯Î¿Ï |url=http://portal.kathimerini.gr/4dcgi/_w_articles_kathbreak_1_21/06/2011_395425 |publisher=www.kathimerini.gr |accessdate=4 July 2011}} Apart from the economic crisis, there is also a developing political crisis in the country. The [[European Commission]] asked the major parties in Greece to come to an agreement in regards to the new set of austerity measures, but twice the major parties failed to come to an agreement.{{cite web|title=XÏÏÎ¯Ï ÏÏÎ½Î±Î¯Î½ÎµÏÎ· ÏÏÎ± ÏÎ»Î­Î³Î¿Î½ÏÎ± Î¸Î­Î¼Î±ÏÎ± |url=http://www.skai.gr/news/politics/article/170679/horis-sunainesi-sta-flegoda-themata/ |publisher=www.skai.gr |accessdate=29 May 2011 |date=27 May 2011}} On a poll published on 29 May 2011, the two major parties (the ruling [[Panhellenic Socialist Movement]] and the main opposition of [[New Democracy (Greece)|New Democracy]]) gather slightly under 40% of the total number of votes, with the ruling party having 19%, while the opposition comes first with 19.5%.{{cite web|title=ÎÏÎ»Î¹Ï ÏÎ¿Ï Î¾ÎµÏÎµÏÎ½Î¬ÎµÎ¹ ÏÎ¿ 40% Î¿ Î´Î¹ÎºÎ¿Î¼Î¼Î±ÏÎ¹ÏÎ¼ÏÏ |url=http://www.enet.gr/?i=news.el.politikh&id=279636 |publisher=www.enet.gr |accessdate=29 May 2011 |date=29 May 2011}} On another poll published the same day, the ruling party came first with 20.7% while the opposition came second with 20.4%. According to the polls, neither of the two parties could form a government, even if they combined forces.{{Citation needed|date=July 2011}} The lack of co-ordination within the government (with conflicting government officials stating opposite 'government positions') also fueled the protests.{{cite web|title=ÎÎ± Î¼Î±Ï ÏÏÎµÎ»Î¬Î½Î¿ÏÎ½! |url=http://www.protothema.gr/politics/article/?aid=124866 |publisher=www.protothema.gr |accessdate=29 May 2011 |date=29 May 2011}} When [[Maria Damanaki]], [[European Commissioner for Maritime Affairs and Fisheries]], stated that "our withdrawal from the Eurozone is on the table, we have to speak frankly" on 25 May,{{cite web|title=ÎÎ¹Î± ÎºÎ¯Î½Î´ÏÎ½Î¿ ÎµÎ¾ÏÎ´Î¿Ï Î±ÏÏ ÏÎ¿ ÎµÏÏÏ Î¼Î¹Î»Î¬ÎµÎ¹ ÎºÎ±Î¹ Î· Î.ÎÎ±Î¼Î±Î½Î¬ÎºÎ· |url=http://www.protothema.gr/politics/article/?aid=124262 |publisher=www.protothema.gr |accessdate=29 May 2011 |date=25 May 2011}} Greek banks lost liquidity equal to 1.5 billion euro from withdrawals in two days.{{cite web|title=Panic Capital Flight in Greece, Depositors Yank 1.5 Billion Euros in 2 Days; EU Wants Severe Bail-Out Conditions Including International Tax Collection |url=http://globaleconomicanalysis.blogspot.com/2011/05/panic-capital-flight-in-greece.html |publisher=Mish's Global Economic Trend Analysis |accessdate=3 July 2011 |date=30 May 2011}}{{cite web|title=Î£Î®ÎºÏÏÎ±Î½ 1,5 Î´Î¹Ï. ÎµÏÏÏ Î Î­Î¼ÏÏÎ· ÎºÎ±Î¹ Î Î±ÏÎ±ÏÎºÎµÏÎ® Î±ÏÏ ÏÎ¹Ï ÏÏÎ¬ÏÎµÎ¶ÎµÏ |url=http://www.protothema.gr/economy/article/?aid=124771 |publisher=www.protothema.gr |accessdate=29 May 2011 |date=28 May 2011}} Meanwhile, the Minister of Finance, [[Giorgos Papakonstantinou]], vehemently denied that exiting the Eurozone is being considered. On 1 June, the leader of the [[Popular Orthodox Rally]] party, [[Georgios Karatzaferis]], announced that his party is considering resigning from parliament, thus causing the dissolution of the [[Hellenic Parliament]] and national elections.{{cite web|title=Î. ÎÎ±ÏÎ±ÏÎ¶Î±ÏÎ­ÏÎ·Ï: Î£ÎºÎ­ÏÏÎ¿Î¼Î±Î¹ Î½Î± Î±ÏÎ¿ÏÏÏÏ ÏÎ¿ ÎÎÎÎ£ Î±ÏÏ ÏÎ· ÎÎ¿ÏÎ»Î® |url=http://www.agelioforos.gr/default.asp?pid=7&ct=10&artid=95412 |publisher=www.agelioforos.gr |accessdate=1 June 2011 |date=1 June 2011}}{{cite web|title=ÎÎ±ÏÎ±ÏÎ¶Î±ÏÎ­ÏÎ·Ï: ÎÎ± ÏÎ¬ÏÏ ÏÎ¿ÏÏ Î²Î¿ÏÎ»ÎµÏÏÎ­Ï Î¼Î¿Ï ÎºÎ±Î¹ Î¸Î± ÏÏÎ³Ï |url=http://www.enet.gr/?i=news.el.politikh&id=280598 |publisher=www.enet.gr |accessdate=1 June 2011 |date=1 June 2011}}{{cite web|title=ÎÎ±ÏÎ±ÏÎ¶Î±ÏÎ­ÏÎ·Ï: ÎÎ¾ÎµÏÎ¬Î¶ÎµÎ¹ ÏÎ·Î½ Î±ÏÎ¿ÏÏÏÎ·ÏÎ· ÏÎ¿Ï ÎÎÎÎ£ Î±ÏÏ ÏÎ· ÎÎ¿ÏÎ»Î® |url=http://www.skai.gr/news/politics/article/171054/karatzaferis-exetazei-tin-apohorisi-tou-laos-apo-ti-vouli-/ |publisher=www.skai.gr |accessdate=1 June 2011 |date=1 June 2011}} He also commented that "I see a Prime Minister that is unable to react, an opposition that is unwilling to play the game and a [[Left (politics)|Left]] that is in its own little world". ==2011 protests== ===February 2011=== On 23 February 2011, there was a recurrence of violent protests and strikes, involving up to 100,000 people{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/europe/2011/02/201122316141729962.html |title=Clashes break out at Greek protests - Europe |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date=2011-02-23 |accessdate=2011-06-30}} as German Chancellor [[Angela Merkel]] called for a renewal of the loan programme to Greece{{cite web|last=Czuczka |first=Tony |url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-02-22/merkel-says-eu-considering-extension-of-financial-aid-program-for-greece.html |title=Merkel Says EU Considering Extension of Financial Aid Program for Greece |publisher=Bloomberg |date=2011-02-23 |accessdate=2011-06-30}} that had been conditioned on fiscal tightening.
