(Greece)|Real Democracy Now!]] information kiosk at Syntagma Square, 31 May.]] As of 25 May 2011, there is a peaceful demonstration in Athens and other major cities, protesting the new austerity measures proposed by the government, in the same spirit as the [[2011 Spanish protests]].{{cite web|url=http://www.sigmalive.com/news/greece/386263 |title=ÎÎ»Î»Î¬Î´Î±: ÏÎ»Î®Î¸Î¿Ï ÏÎ¿Î»Î¹ÏÏÎ½ Î´Î¹Î±Î´Î®Î»ÏÏÎ±Î½ Î³Î¹Î± ÏÎ± Î¼Î­ÏÏÎ± Î»Î¹ÏÏÏÎ·ÏÎ±Ï |publisher=Sigma Live |date= |accessdate=2011-06-30}}{{cite web |url=http://www.enet.gr/?i=news.el.politikh&id=278646 |title=ÎÎ¯ÏÏÏ ÎºÏÎ¼Î¼Î±, ÏÏÎ½Î´Î¹ÎºÎ¬ÏÎ¿, Î¼ÏÎ½Î¿ Î¿ÏÎ³Î® (Without a party or syndicate, just anger) |language=Greek |date=26 May 2011 |publisher=www.eleftherotypia.gr |accessdate=26 May 2011}} The demonstrations span across most major Greek cities, including [[Athens]], [[Thessaloniki]], [[Larissa]], [[Patras]], [[Volos]], [[Rethymno]], [[Tripoli (Greece)|Tripoli]] and [[Kalamata]], some of Greece's largest cities.{{cite web |url=http://www.ert.gr/index.php/eidiseis/ellada/38-koinonia/6516-2011-05-26-18-55-52.html |title=ÎÎ­Î± ÏÏÎ³ÎºÎ­Î½ÏÏÏÏÎ· ÏÏÎ¿ Î£ÏÎ½ÏÎ±Î³Î¼Î± (New demonstration at Syntagma) |language=Greek |date=26 May 2011 |publisher=www.news.ert.gr |accessdate=26 May 2011}}{{cite web|author=ÎÎ»Î»Î¬Î´Î± |url=http://www.greek-radar.gr/iaganaktismeni-polites-sigkentrononte-sto-sintagma/ |title=ÎÎ»Î»Î¬Î´Î± - Î Î¬Î½Ï Î±ÏÏ 20.000 Î¿Î¹ "Î±Î³Î±Î½Î±ÎºÏÎ¹ÏÎ¼Î­Î½Î¿Î¹'' ÏÎ¿Î»Î¯ÏÎµÏ ÏÏÎ¿ Î£ÏÎ½ÏÎ±Î³Î¼Î±! |date=2010-10-29 |accessdate=2011-06-30}}{{cite web |url=http://www.skai.gr/news/greece/article/170493/oi-aganaktismenoi-diadilonoun-stis-ellinikes-poleis-/ |title=ÎÎ¹ "ÎÎ³Î±Î½Î±ÎºÏÎ¹ÏÎ¼Î­Î½Î¿Î¹" Î´Î¹Î±Î´Î·Î»ÏÎ½Î¿ÏÎ½ ÏÏÎ¹Ï ÎµÎ»Î»Î·Î½Î¹ÎºÎ­Ï ÏÏÎ»ÎµÎ¹Ï (The 'indignants' protest in Greek cities) |language=Greek |date=26 May 2011 |publisher=www.skai.gr |accessdate=26 May 2011}} The demonstration in Athens is coordinated by the Facebook page "ÎÎ³Î±Î½Î±ÎºÏÎ¹ÏÎ¼Î­Î½Î¿Î¹ Î£ÏÎ¿ Î£ÏÎ½ÏÎ±Î³Î¼Î±" (Indignants at [[Syntagma Square|Syntagma]]).{{cite web |url=https://www.facebook.com/pages/%CE%91%CE%B3%CE%B1%CE%BD%CE%B1%CE%BA%CF%84%CE%B9%CF%83%CE%BC%CE%B5%CE%BD%CE%BF%CE%B9-%CE%A3%CF%84%CE%BF-%CE%A3%CF%85%CE%BD%CF%84%CE%B1%CE%B3%CE%BC%CE%B1/210627972310743 |title=ÎÎ³Î±Î½Î±ÎºÏÎ¹ÏÎ¼ÎµÎ½Î¿Î¹ Î£ÏÎ¿ Î£ÏÎ½ÏÎ±Î³Î¼Î± |language=Greek |date=26 May 2011 |publisher=www.facebook.com |accessdate=26 May 2011}} Currently, it is reported that over 90,000 people have registered at the page,{{cite web|url=http://www.newsplus.gr/index.php?v=2&aid=34149 |title=newsplus | Î§Î¹Î»Î¹Î¬Î´ÎµÏ ÎÎ»Î»Î·Î½ÎµÏ Î´Î·Î»ÏÎ½Î¿ÏÎ½ ..."Î Î¬Î¼Îµ Î Î»Î±ÏÎµÎ¯Î±"! - ÎÎ»Î»Î¬Î´Î±, ÎºÎ¿Î¹Î½ÏÎ½Î¯Î± |publisher=Newsplus.gr |date= |accessdate=2011-06-30}} and thousands (reportedly over 30,000) have gathered outside the [[Hellenic Parliament|Greek Parliament]] in Syntagma square.{{cite web|url=http://www.star.gr/ellada_kosmos/93174/ |title=Î£Îµ ÎµÎ¾Î­Î»Î¹Î¾Î· Î· ÏÏÎ³ÎºÎ­Î½ÏÏÏÏÎ· ÏÏÎ½ "ÎÎ³Î±Î½Î±ÎºÏÎ¹ÏÎ¼Î­Î½ÏÎ½" ÏÏÎ¿ Î£ÏÎ½ÏÎ±Î³Î¼Î± |publisher=Star.Gr |date=2010-10-07 |accessdate=2011-06-30}}[http://roarmag.org/2011/05/greek-revolution-protests-live-stream-syntagma-square/ Livestream of the protests at Syntagma Square, Athens | Reflections on a Revolution ROAR] The demonstration in Greece's second-largest city, [[Thessaloniki]], is co-ordinated by the Facebook page "ÎÎ³Î±Î½Î±ÎºÏÎ¹ÏÎ¼Î­Î½Î¿Î¹ ÏÏÎ¿Î½ ÎÎµÏÎºÏ Î ÏÏÎ³Î¿" (Indignants at the [[White Tower of Thessaloniki|White Tower]]), and over 35,000 people have said they would 'attend' the protest.{{cite web |url=http://www.facebook.com/event.php?eid=206334352736094&ref=ts |title=ÎÎÎÎÎÎÎ¤ÎÎ£ÎÎÎÎÎ Î£Î¤ÎÎ ÎÎÎ¥ÎÎ Î Î¥Î¡ÎÎ |language=Greek |date=26 May 2011 |publisher=www.facebook.com |accessdate=26 May 2011}} Some of the most popular slogans at the 25 May protest were: *Error 404, Democracy was not found.{{cite news|url=http://www.abc.es/agencias/noticia.asp?noticia=841597|title=Sinde recibida en San SebastiÃ¡n por los "indignados" al grito de "fuera"|date=6 June 2011|publisher=ABC PeriÃ³dico ElectrÃ³nico|language=Spanish|accessdate=12 June 2011}} *I vote, You vote, He votes, She votes, We vote, You vote, They steal. *Greece your turn has come, you have to stop burying your children.{{cite web |url=http://makthes.gr/news/reportage/74247/ |title=ÎÎ³Î±Î½Î¬ÎºÏÎ·ÏÎ±Î½ Î¿Î¹ ÏÎ¿Î»Î¯ÏÎµÏ |language=Greek |date=26 May 2011 |publisher=www.makthes.gr |accessdate=26 May 2011}} *Oust! (Greek interjection of a negative nature, meaning "leave") *The maid resisted. What do we do? (Reference to [[Dominique Strauss-Kahn sexual assault case|an alleged sex scandal]] involving former IMF director [[Dominique Strauss-Kahn]]) This series of demonstrations differed from almost all other demonstrations in Greece's [[metapolitefsi]] era (1975âpresent) in that it was a protest organized without involving any political or trade union affiliations. Demonstrators who expressed affiliation to any political party during the demonstrations were condemned by the majority of the demonstrators, as the organizers claimed that there is no room for political affiliations and violence in these demonstrations. The focus of the protesters was mostly against the government and the current driving forces of [[Politics of Greece|Greek politics]], as well as the [[International Monetary Fund]]. As a response to the Spanish slogan "Be quiet, the Greeks are sleeping" (which was allegedly heard at the [[2011 Spanish protests]]),{{cite web |url=http://www.enet.gr/?i=issue.el.home&date=25/05/2011&id=278406 |title=Î¤Î¿ ÏÏÎ½Î¸Î·Î¼Î± ÏÎ¿Ï Î¬ÎºÎ¿ÏÏÎ±Î½ Î¼ÏÎ½Î¿ ÏÎ± ÎµÎ»Î»Î·Î½Î¹ÎºÎ¬ ÎÎÎ (The slogan that only Greek media heard) |language=Greek |date=25 May 2011 |publisher=www.enet.gr |accessdate=26 May 2011}} a big banner was raised in front of the Spanish embassy in Athens reading "Â¡Estamos despiertos! Â¿Que hora es? Â¡Ya es hora de que se vayan!" (We've woken up! What time is it? Its time they left!).{{cite web |url=http://www.e-typos.com/content.aspx?cid=23219&catid=7 |title=EÎ»Î»Î¬Î´Î±: Î¥ÏÏ Î²ÏÎ¿ÏÎ®, Î±Î»Î»Î¬ ÏÎ¹ÏÏÎ¿Î¯ ÏÏÎ¿ ÏÎ±Î½ÏÎµÎ²Î¿Ï ÏÏÎ¿ Î£ÏÎ½ÏÎ±Î³Î¼Î±, Î¿Î¹ "ÎÎ³Î±Î½Î±ÎºÏÎ¹ÏÎ¼Î­Î½Î¿Î¹" ÏÎ¿Î»Î¯ÏÎµÏ (Greece: under the rain the "outraged" citizens are at Syntagma again") |language=Greek |date=26 May 2011 |publisher=www.e-typos.gr |accessdate=26 May 2011}} There was also a strong sense of disapproval for the [[Prime Minister of Greece]], [[George Papandreou]], and the vice-president of the government, [[Theodoros Pangalos]].{{cite web |url=http://www.enet.gr/?i=news.el.ellada&id=278917 |title=Î Î±Î³Î±Î½Î¬ÎºÏÎ·ÏÎ· Î½Î¯ÎºÎ·ÏÎµ ÏÎ·Î½ ÎºÎ±ÏÎ±Î¹Î³Î¯Î´Î± |language=Greek |date=26 May 2011 |publisher=www.enet.gr |accessdate=27 May 2011}} The demonstrations continued nation-wide for a second day on 26 May.{{cite web |url=http://makthes.gr/news/reportage/74247/ |title=ÎÎ³Î±Î½Î¬ÎºÏÎ·ÏÎ±Î½ Î¿Î¹ ÏÎ¿Î»Î¯ÏÎµÏ (The citizens are outraged) |language=Greek |date=26 May 2011 |publisher=www.makthes.gr |accessdate=26 May 2011}}{{cite web |url=http://www.skai.gr/news/greece/article/170575/i-diamarturia-sto-sudagma-zodana-sto-skaigr/ |title=ÎÎ¹ Î´Î¹Î±Î¼Î±ÏÏÏÏÎ¯ÎµÏ ÏÎµ Î£ÏÎ½ÏÎ±Î³Î¼Î± ÎºÎ±Î¹ Î Î¬ÏÏÎ± Î¶ÏÎ½ÏÎ±Î½Î¬ ÏÏÎ¿ SKAI.gr (The demonstrations at Syntagma and Patras live on SKAI.gr) |language=Greek |date=26 May 2011 |publisher=www.skai.gr |accessdate=26 May 2011}} Despite the heavy rainfall in central Athens, thousands of people, reportedly over 14,000, gathered in front of the Greek parliament for a second day in a row.{{cite web |url=http://www.skai.gr/player/TV/?MMID=214612 |title=Î£ÏÎ½ÎµÏÎ¯Î¶Î¿Î½ÏÎ±Î¹ Î¿Î¹ Î´Î¹Î±Î¼Î±ÏÏÏÏÎ¯ÎµÏ |language=Greek |date=26 May 2011 |publisher=www.skai.gr |accessdate=26 May 2011}} The media reported that about half of the people gathered at Syntagma Square in Athens were youth, whereas the other half were over 40, including families and children. In line with the Spanish quote of "Be quiet, the Greeks are sleeping" which triggered the Greek protests, two new banners appeared, one in French (Silence! Les FranÃ§ais dorment! Ils revent de '68, ''Silence! The French are sleeping! They are dreaming the (May) '68'') and one in Italian (Zitti che svegliamo gli Italiani... ''Be quiet, you will wake up the Italians...''). An information center and a "book of ideas" have also been set up at Syntagma Square.{{cite web |url=http://www.skai.gr/player/tv/?mmid=214618 |title=Î§Î¹Î»Î¹Î¬Î´ÎµÏ ÏÎ¿Î»Î¯ÏÎµÏ ÎºÎ±Î¹ ÎµÏÎ¸Î­Ï ÏÏÎ¿ Î£ÏÎ½ÏÎ±Î³Î¼Î± |language=Greek |date=27 May 2011 |publisher=www.skai.gr |accessdate=27 May 2011}} Additionally, a number of people were banging pots and caceroles. In [[Thessaloniki]], Greece's second city and second-largest center of demonstrations, the protesters hang a big banner from the city's main landmark, the [[White Tower of Thessaloniki|White Tower]], saying "for sale" as a protest against the government's massive denationalization schedule, which they perceived as "selling away our country's assets".{{cite web |url=http://makthes.gr/news/reportage/74304/ |title=ÎÎ±Î½Î¬ ÏÏÎ¿Î½ ÎÎµÏÎºÏ Î ÏÏÎ³Î¿ Î¿Î¹ Î±Î³Î±Î½Î±ÎºÏÎ¹ÏÎ¼Î­Î½Î¿Î¹ |language=Greek |date=27 May 2011 |publisher=www.makthes.gr |accessdate=27 May 2011}}{{cite web |url=http://www.agelioforos.gr/default.asp?pid=7&ct=1&artid=94610 |title=ÎÎµÏÏÎ±Î»Î¿Î½Î¯ÎºÎ·: Î£Î®Î¼ÎµÏÎ± ÏÏÎ¹Ï 18:00 Î³Î¹Î± ÏÏÎ¯ÏÎ· Î·Î¼Î­ÏÎ± ÏÏÎ¿Î½ ÎÎµÏÎºÏ Î ÏÏÎ³Î¿ Î¿Î¹ "ÎÎ³Î±Î½Î±ÎºÏÎ¹ÏÎ¼Î­Î½Î¿Î¹" |language=Greek |date=27 May 2011 |publisher=www.agelioforos.gr |accessdate=27 May 2011}} Although the demonstrations in Thessaloniki were visibly smaller on 26 May, with around 2,500 people participating, presumably because there was a major football game between the city's two major teams and the markets were open until late that evening, some people have set up encampments. In Thessaloniki's protests there is much more of a sense of direct democracy, as citizens are free to take the floor and speak, voice their concerns and opinions and contribute ideas about what should be done next, while they receive the full attention and respect of the other demonstrators.{{cite web |url=http://www.agelioforos.gr/default.asp?pid=7&ct=1&artid=94405 |title=ÎÎ±Î¹ ÏÎ®Î¼ÎµÏÎ± Î¬ÏÏÎ¹ÏÎ±Î½ Î½Î± ÏÏÎ³ÎºÎµÎ½ÏÏÏÎ½Î¿Î½ÏÎ±Î¹ ÏÏÎ¿Î½ ÎÎµÏÎºÏ Î ÏÏÎ³Î¿ Î¿Î¹ "ÎÎ³Î±Î½Î±ÎºÏÎ¹ÏÎ¼Î­Î½Î¿Î¹" |language=Greek |date=26 May 2011 |publisher=www.agelioforos.gr |accessdate=27 May 2011}} [[File:Vote of the People's Assembly of Syntagma Square.svg|thumb|The first vote of the people's assembly of Syntagma Square.{{cite web |url=http://real-democracy.gr/el/%CF%88%CE%AE%CF%86%CE%B9%CF%83%CE%BC%CE%B1-%CE%BB%CE%B1%CF%8A%CE%BA%CE%AE%CF%82-%CF%83%CF%85%CE%BD%CE%AD%CE%BB%CE%B5%CF%85%CF%83%CE%B7%CF%82-%CF%80%CE%BB%CE%B1%CF%84%CE%B5%CE%AF%CE%B1%CF%82-%CF%83%CF%85%CE%BD%CF%84%CE%AC%CE%B3%CE%BC%CE%B1%CF%84%CE%BF%CF%82-0 |title=Î¨Î®ÏÎ¹ÏÎ¼Î± Î»Î±ÏÎºÎ®Ï ÏÏÎ½Î­Î»ÎµÏÏÎ·Ï Î Î»Î±ÏÎµÎ¯Î±Ï Î£ÏÎ½ÏÎ¬Î³Î¼Î±ÏÎ¿Ï |language=Greek |publisher=www.real-democracy.gr |accessdate=31 May 2011}}]] Demonstrations continued for a third consecutive day on 27 May.{{cite web |url=http://www.protothema.gr/greece/article/?aid=124746 |title=Î£ÏÎ¿ Î£ÏÎ½ÏÎ±Î³Î¼Î± Î³Î¹Î± ÏÏÎ¯ÏÎ· Î¼Î­ÏÎ± Î¿Î¹ ÎÎ³Î±Î½Î±ÎºÏÎ¹ÏÎ¼Î­Î½Î¿Î¹ |language=Greek |date=27 May 2011 |publisher=www.protothema.gr |accessdate=27 May 2011}}{{cite web |url=http://www.skai.gr/news/greece/article/170612/neo-radevou-apo-tous-aganaktismenous/ |title=ÎÎ­Î¿ ÏÎ±Î½ÏÎµÎ²Î¿Ï Î±ÏÏ ÏÎ¿ÏÏ "ÎÎ³Î±Î½Î±ÎºÏÎ¹ÏÎ¼Î­Î½Î¿ÏÏ" |language=Greek |date=27 May 2011 |publisher=www.skai.gr |accessdate=27 May 2011}} Thousands of people gathered in front of the Greek parliament, despite the heavy downpour again, and this time they were joined by the "I'm Not Paying" movement. As a means of protesting, people wearing white masks formed a human shield around the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier, which is within Syntagma Square. The demonstrations continued to be peaceful, and when one protester shouted a slogan against the police, he was heavily condemned by the other demonstrators. On 27 May, the proceedings of the first [[Popular assembly|people's assembly]] on Syntagma Square were published by the [[Real Democracy Now! (Greece)|Real Democracy Now!]] movement. Among them:{{cite web |url=http://real-democracy.gr/node/47 |title=Proceedings of the First Assembly |language=Greek |date=26 May 2011 |publisher=www.real-democracy.gr |accessdate=26 May 2011}} *Any wrong-doing politician should either be sent home or to jail. *When we, the people, start discussions without fear, fear grasps them, inside the parliament building. *This is not just the politician's fault. Its all our faults, with our selfish attitudes. *Demonstrations should take place every evening at 6 pm and an [[Popular assembly|assembly]] at 9 pm. *Their democracy guarantees neither Justice nor Equality. *The taxation system is not the same for the rich and the poor. Equal rights for everyone. On 28 May, demonstrations continued with at least 7,000 people gathered in front of the Greek parliament.{{cite web |url=http://www.star.gr/ellada_kosmos/93565 |title="ÎÎ³Î±Î½Î±ÎºÏÎ¹ÏÎ¼Î­Î½Î¿Î¹": "ÎµÎ¯ÏÏÎµ ÏÏÎ¿Î´ÏÏÎµÏ" |language=Greek |date=28 May 2011 |publisher=www.star.gr |accessdate=28 May 2011}} A number of new flags appeared that day, including those of Tunisia, Argentina, Armenia and Hungary. At least 20 people have set up tents in the square. Major demonstrations also took place in Thessaloniki, Patras and Heraklion.{{cite web |url=http://www.star.gr/politics/93597/ |title="ÎÏÎ¹Î¼Î­Î½Î¿ÏÎ½ Î³Î¹Î± ÏÎ­ÏÎ±ÏÏÎ· Î¼Î­ÏÎ± Î¿Î¹ "ÎÎ³Î±Î½Î±ÎºÏÎ¹ÏÎ¼Î­Î½Î¿Î¹" |language=Greek |date=28 May 2011 |publisher=www.star.gr |accessdate=28 May 2011}} Additionally, in Thessaloniki a cycling race was also organized as part of the demonstration.{{cite web |url=http://www.enet.gr/?i=news.el.ellada&id=279623 |title=ÎÎ¹ ÏÎ»Î±ÏÎµÎ¯ÎµÏ ÎµÎ¯Î½Î±Î¹ Î³ÎµÎ¼Î¬ÏÎµÏ Î³Î¹Î± 4Î· Î¼Î­ÏÎ± |language=Greek |date=28 May 2011 |publisher=www.enet.gr |accessdate=28 May 2011}} All across the country the movement is getting more organized, media report, with teams of doctors, translators, food suppliers and the like being set up by the protesters, especially at Syntagma Square, which has turned into the main protest center in the country. [[File:2011 Greece Uprising.jpg|thumb|Demonstrators in front of the Greek parliament, 29 May.]] 29 May was set as a day of peaceful pan-European demonstrations.{{cite web |url=http://www.facebook.com/event.php?eid=225690444124218 |title=EUROPEAN REVOLUTION 29 MAYâALL CITIES OF EUROPE |language=Greek |date=26 May 2011 |publisher=www.facebook.com |accessdate=26 May 2011}} It is estimated that the demonstration in Athens alone attracted more than 100,000 demonstrators in front of the Greek parliament,{{cite web |url=http://www.skai.gr/news/greece/article/170780/pano-apo-100000-oi-aganaktismenoi-sto-sudagma-/ |title=Î£ÏÎ¿ÏÏ 100.000 Î¿Î¹ "ÎÎ³Î±Î½Î±ÎºÏÎ¹ÏÎ¼Î­Î½Î¿Î¹ ÏÏÎ¿ Î£ÏÎ½ÏÎ±Î³Î¼Î±" |language=Greek |date=29 May 2011 |publisher=www.skai.gr |accessdate=29 May 2011}}{{cite web |url=http://www.protothema.gr/greece/article/?aid=125014 |title=100.000 ÏÎ¿Î»Î¯ÏÎµÏ Î²Î¿ÏÎ»Î¹Î¬Î¶Î¿ÏÎ½ ÏÎ¿ Î£ÏÎ½ÏÎ±Î³Î¼Î±! |language=Greek |date=29 May 2011 |publisher=www.protothema.gr |accessdate=29 May 2011}}{{cite news |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/BUSINESS/05/30/greece.bailout.ft/index.html |title=Greece set for severe bail-out conditions |date=29 May 2011 |publisher=CNN |accessdate=29 May 2011}} {{Dead link|date=September 2011|bot=RjwilmsiBot}}{{cite web |url=http://www.euronews.net/2011/05/29/spanish-inspired-protest-grips-athens/ |title=Spanish-inspired protest grips Athens |date=29 May 2011 |publisher=www.euronews.eu |accessdate=29 May 2011}} while others put the estimates down to 80,000.{{cite web |url=http://www.skai.gr/news/greece/article/170810/neo-radevou-ton-aganaktismenon-to-apogeuma-tis-deuteras/ |title= Î Î¹ÏÏÎ¿Î¯ ÏÏÎ¿ Î­ÎºÏÎ¿ ÏÎ±Î½ÏÎµÎ²Î¿Ï ÏÎ¿ÏÏ Î¿Î¹ "ÎÎ³Î±Î½Î±ÎºÏÎ¹ÏÎ¼Î­Î½Î¿Î¹" |language=Greek |date=30 May 2011 |publisher=www.skai.gr |accessdate=31 May 2011}} Demonstrations included people of all ages and financial backgrounds, and the oldest person at the demonstration in front of the Parliament was a 102-year-old grandmother looking after her granddaughter, who also spoke at the [[Popular assembly|people's assembly]] in support of the demonstrations.{{cite web |url=http://www.ethnos.gr/article.asp?catid=22768&subid=2&pubid=63105080 |title=Î Î¼ÎµÎ³Î±Î»ÏÏÎµÏÎ· Î²ÏÎ±Î´Î¹Î¬ ÏÎ·Ï Î±Î³Î±Î½Î¬ÎºÏÎ·ÏÎ·Ï |date=29 May 2011 |publisher=www.protothema.gr |accessdate=29 May 2011}} An estimated 10,000 people gathered in front of the [[White Tower of Thessaloniki]] in Greece's second city, and demonstrations were also held in many other Greek cities.{{cite web |url=http://makthes.gr/news/reportage/74531/ |title=Î£Î±Ï ÏÎµÏÎ¹Î¼Î­Î½Î¿ÏÎ¼Îµ ÏÏÎ¿Î½ Î ÏÏÎ³Î¿ ÏÎ¿ ÎÎµÏÎºÏ... |date=30 May 2011 |publisher=www.makthes.gr |accessdate=30 May 2011}} Some of the most popular slogans that were heard on 29 May were "the worst form of violence is poverty" and "a magical night, like in Argentina, lets see who gets in the helicopter first!", a reference to [[President of Argentina|Argentine President]] [[Fernando de la RÃºa]]'s resignation and escape from the presidential mansion using a helicopter in 2001. Some of the demands that the [[Real Democracy Now! (Greece)|Real Democracy Now!]] movement has formulated during the [[Popular assembly|assemblies]] at syntagma Square include:{{cite web |url=http://real-democracy.gr/el/%CF%83%CF%84%CF%8C%CF%87%CE%BF%CE%B9-%CF%84%CE%BF%CF%85-%CE%BA%CE%B9%CE%BD%CE%AE%CE%BC%CE%B1%CF%84%CE%BF%CF%82%CF%83%CF%85%CE%B6%CE%B7%CF%84%CE%AE%CF%83%CE%B5%CE%B9%CF%82 |title=Î£ÏÏÏÎ¿Î¹ ÏÎ¿Ï ÎºÎ¹Î½Î®Î¼Î±ÏÎ¿Ï/Î£ÏÎ¶Î·ÏÎ®ÏÎµÎ¹Ï |date=27 May 2011 |publisher=www.real-democracy.gr |accessdate=30 May 2011}} *Adoption of a new constitution, written by the people and not the members of parliament *Refusal to pay debt which members of the movement consider to be [[odious debt|odious]] *Cancellation of the memorandum signed between Greece and the [[International Monetary Fund]] *Harder taxation on the rich. [[File:Vote of the People's Assembly of the White Tower Square.svg|thumb|A similar vote was issued by the people's assembly in Thessaloniki.{{cite web |url=http://aganaktismenoi-thess.blogspot.com/2011/05/3005.html |title=Î¨ÎÎ¦ÎÎ£ÎÎ Î¤ÎÎ£ Î£Î¥ÎÎÎÎÎ¥Î£ÎÎ£ Î¤ÎÎ¥ ÎÎÎ¥ÎÎÎ¥ Î Î¥Î¡ÎÎÎ¥ 30/05 |language=Greek |date=30 May 2011 |publisher=www.aganaktismenoi-thess.blogspot.com |accessdate=31 May 2011}}]] 30 May saw continued demonstrations in Athens and other cities around Greece, although visibly smaller than the demonstrations of 29 May.{{cite web |url=http://makthes.gr/news/politics/74556/ |title=ÎÎ¹Î± 6Î· Î¼Î­ÏÎ± Î¿Î¹ "Î±Î³Î±Î½Î±ÎºÏÎ¹ÏÎ¼Î­Î½Î¿Î¹" ÏÏÎ¿Î½ ÎÎµÏÎºÏ Î ÏÏÎ³Î¿ |date=30 May 2011 |publisher=www.makthes.gr |accessdate=31 May 2011}}{{cite web |url=http://www.enet.gr/?i=news.el.politikh&id=280019 |title=Î¨Î·Î»Î±ÏÏÎ½ÏÎ±Ï ÏÎ·Î½ ÎÎ¼ÎµÏÎ· ÎÎ·Î¼Î¿ÎºÏÎ±ÏÎ¯Î± |date=31 May 2011 |publisher=www.enet.gr |accessdate=31 May 2011}} More than 4,000 people demonstrated in front of the Greek parliament on 30 May,{{cite web |url=http://www.ethnos.gr/article.asp?catid=22768&subid=2&pubid=63105303 |title=Î£ÏÎ·Î½ ÏÎ»Î±ÏÎµÎ¯Î± ÏÎ¬Î»Î¹ Î¿Î¹ "ÎÎ³Î±Î½Î±ÎºÏÎ¹ÏÎ¼Î­Î½Î¿Î¹" |date=30 May 2011 |publisher=www.ethnos.gr |accessdate=31 May 2011}} with some sources claiming that over 10,000 people were present.{{cite web |url=http://www.protothema.gr/greece/article/?aid=125447 |title=ÎÎ­Î¿ ÏÎ±Î½ÏÎµÎ²Î¿Ï ÏÏÎ½ ÎÎ³Î±Î½Î±ÎºÏÎ¹ÏÎ¼Î­Î½ÏÎ½ ÏÏÎ¿ Î£ÏÎ½ÏÎ±Î³Î¼Î± |date=31 May 2011 |publisher=www.protothema.gr |accessdate=31 May 2011}} The demonstrators also set up a set of [[gallow]]s in front of the parliament, demanding that those responsible for the crisis be sent to justice. Over 30 tents have been set up in front of the [[White Tower of Thessaloniki]] in Greece's second-largest city, where a direct democracy style [[Popular assembly|people's assembly]] takes place every evening. 31 May marked seven days since the start of the protests, and the [[University of Athens]] hosted an anti-government protest with the aid of famous Greek composer and anti-dictatorship fighter [[Mikis Theodorakis]], while the dean of the University was also a key speaker at the event. Once the protest at the university was over, the 10,000 protesters joined forces with the demonstrators already in front of the parliament.{{cite web |url=http://www.protothema.gr/greece/article/?aid=125447 |title=50.000 ÏÎ¿Î»Î¯ÏÎµÏ ÏÏÎ¿ ÎºÎ­Î½ÏÏÎ¿ ÏÎ·Ï ÎÎ¸Î®Î½Î±Ï |language=Greek |date=31 May 2011 |publisher=www.protothema.gr |accessdate=31 May 2011}} The total number of demonstrators was between 25,000 and 50,000{{cite web |url=http://www.skai.gr/news/greece/article/170979/evdomi-imera-aganaktisis/ |title=Î£Îµ "ÎºÎ±ÏÎ¬ÏÏÎ±ÏÎ· ÏÎ¿Î»Î¹Î¿ÏÎºÎ¯Î±Ï" ÏÎ¿ ÎÎ¿Î¹Î½Î¿Î²Î¿ÏÎ»Î¹Î¿ |language=Greek |date=31 May 2011 |publisher=www.skai.gr |accessdate=31 May 2011}} and the demonstrators had surrounded the Greek parliament, making it impossible for MPs and workers inside the building to come out, while 8 MPs were able to escape through the adjacent National Gardens. Later riot police created a passage in order to enable MPs to exit the parliament, but the 1,000 protesters gathered at the side entrance of the parliament condemned all the members of parliament that exited the building.{{cite web |url=http://www.protothema.gr/greece/article/?aid=125512 |title=ÎÏÏÎ±ÎºÏÏ Î· ÎµÎ¯ÏÎ¿Î´Î¿Ï ÏÎ·Ï ÎÎ¿ÏÎ»Î®Ï |language=Greek |date=31 May 2011 |publisher=www.protothema.gr |accessdate=31 May 2011}} ====June==== Demonstrations continued on 1 June. At [[Corfu]], protesters surrounded a restaurant where Greek and foreign members of parliament were having a dinner, shouting slogans against them while a few were throwing rocks and other objects at the politicians.{{cite web |url=http://www.protothema.gr/greece/article/?aid=125669 |title=ÎÏÏÎ³Î±Î½ Î¼Îµ ÏÎºÎ¬ÏÎ¿Ï Î³Î¹Î± Î½Î± Î³Î»Î¹ÏÏÏÎ¿ÏÎ½ Î±ÏÏ ÏÎ¿ÏÏ ÎÎ³Î±Î½Î±ÎºÏÎ¹ÏÎ¼Î­Î½Î¿ÏÏ |language=Greek |date=2 June 2011 |publisher=www.protothema.gr |accessdate=2 June 2011}}{{cite web |url=http://www.skai.gr/news/greece/article/171153/bloko-aganaktismenon-se-vouleutes-stin-kerkura/ |title="ÎÏÎ»ÏÎºÎ¿" Î±Î³Î±Î½Î±ÎºÏÎ¹ÏÎ¼Î­Î½ÏÎ½ ÏÎµ Î²Î¿ÏÎ»ÎµÏÏÎ­Ï ÏÏÎ·Î½ ÎÎ­ÏÎºÏÏÎ± |language=Greek |date=2 June 2011 |publisher=www.skai.gr |accessdate=2 June 2011}}{{cite web |url=http://www.enet.gr/?i=news.el.ellada&id=280706 |title=ÎÎ¿ÏÎ»ÎµÏÏÎ­Ï ÏÏÎ³Î±Î´ÎµÏÎ¸Î·ÎºÎ±Î½ Î¼Îµ... ÎºÎ±ÎÎºÎ¹ ÏÏÎ·Î½ ÎÎ­ÏÎºÏÏÎ± |language=Greek |date=2 June 2011 |publisher=www.enet.gr |accessdate=2 June 2011}} Finally, the officials were forced to escape using a boat, as the restaurant was near the harbor. In Athens, more than 15,000 people gathered in front of the parliament to protest for an eighth day in a row. This time they were also joined by the ''Society for the Protection of Citizens by the Arbitration of Banks'', and also a group of motorcyclists who also showed their support for the protests. Earlier that evening the riot police had closed up the streets leading up to the embassy of Egypt. In order to avoid being blockaded inside the parliament like on 31 May, the members of parliament left early on 1 June. Among thousands of protesters in Syntagma square, 32 Greek scientists addressed a letter to the members of parliament calling them to announce the whole truth of the situation{{cite web |url=http://www.zougla.gr/page.ashx?pid=2&aid=322783&cid=6 |title=Î¤Î¿Î»Î¼Î®ÏÏÎµ! |language=Greek |date==1 June 2011 |publisher=www.zougla.gr |accessdate=2 June 2011}} [[image:Greek indignants cleaning streets, day 22.png|thumb|Indignants cleaning the streets around Syntagma Square on their 22nd day of protest on 15 June.]] 5 June was set as a second day of pan-European demonstrations and marked the 12th continuous day of demonstrations. It is estimated that well over 200,000 gathered at Athens' [[Syntagma Square]] that evening to protest against the government.{{cite web |url=http://www.skai.gr/news/greece/article/171424/aganaktismenoi-protofanis-summetohi-se-athina-kai-alles-poleis-/ |title="ÎÎ³Î±Î½Î±ÎºÏÎ¹ÏÎ¼Î­Î½Î¿Î¹": Î ÏÏÏÎ¿ÏÎ±Î½Î®Ï ÏÏÎ¼Î¼ÎµÏÎ¿ÏÎ® ÏÎµ ÎÎ¸Î®Î½Î± ÎºÎ±Î¹ Î¬Î»Î»ÎµÏ ÏÏÎ»ÎµÎ¹Ï |language=Greek |date=5 June 2011 |publisher=www.skai.gr |accessdate=5 June 2011}}{{cite web |url=http://www.enet.gr/?i=news.el.ellada&id=281844 |title=ÎÎºÎºÏÏÎ±Î½ÏÎ¹ÎºÎ® Î»Î±Î¿Î¸Î¬Î»Î±ÏÏÎ± ÏÏÎ¿ Î£ÏÎ½ÏÎ±Î³Î¼Î± |language=Greek |date=5 June 2011 |publisher=www.enet.gr |accessdate=5 June 2011}} Some sources put the number of people in front of the parliament to over 300,000{{cite web |url=http://www.protothema.gr/greece/article/?aid=126165 |title=300.000 ÏÎ¿Î»Î¯ÏÎµÏ ÏÏÎ¿ ÎºÎ­Î½ÏÏÎ¿ ÏÎ·Ï ÎÎ¸Î®Î½Î±Ï! |language=Greek |date=5 June 2011 |publisher=www.skai.gr |accessdate=5 June 2011}} while the organizers claim that over 500,000 people took part in the demonstration, making it the largest demonstration in Athens since the 1980s. At the [[popular assembly|people's assembly]] a direct connection with [[Madrid]]'s [[Puerta del Sol]] was made via [[Skype]]. Some tension occurred on 5 June, as protesters were prevented from heading towards [[Syntagma Square]] by riot police, which had put together large metallic barriers to close off streets. Police also brought a [[water cannon]] to the protests. Demonstrations also took place in [[Thessaloniki]], [[Patras]] and [[Heraklion]], as well as many other Greek cities. Some of the most popular slogans of that day included: *Bread-Education-Freedom â the dictatorship didnt fall in '73! *We do not owe, we will not sell away, we will not pay. *Minister of culture, minister of censorship [[image:June 29 Athens street fire.png|thumb|A bin on fire during the 29 June riots in a street near parliament.]] [[Image:20110629 Old man hit by Riot Police in demonstrations in Athens Greece.jpg|thumb|Clash between riot police and a citizen - 29 June 2011.]] Demonstrations continued throughout June, both at [[Syntagma Square]] and other squares in cities across the country. On 28 June 2011, Greek unions, including those whose members dominate the country's health, transportation, education, and government jobs began a 48-hour strike, in protest of the deteriorating economic situation and suggestions on the part of the government of new austerity measures.{{cite web |url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/international/greek-unions-launch-48-hour-strike-against-austerity-measures-1.370020 |title=Greek unions launch 48-hour strike against austerity measures |date=28 June 2011 |publisher=www.haaretz.com |accessdate=29 June 2011}} The walkout led to the freezing of a number of public services. Journalists and a number of artists also stopped working in solidarity with the protest. That day demonstrations turned violent as protestors clashed with police in front of the Greek parliament and other areas of central [[Athens]]. Violence continued during the night and on 29 June, the day when a new package of deeply unpopular austerity measures was passed.{{cite news |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-13953077 |title=Greece crisis: Greece crisis: MPs vote on austerity package |accessdate=29 June 2011 | work=BBC News |date=29 June 2011}} The police attempted to evacuate Syntagma Square of protesters, as well as other key protest points in Athens, by driving through the crowds on motorbikes and throwing stun grenades while making extensive use of tear gas.{{cite web |url=http://www.skai.gr/news/greece/article/173545/se-pedio-mahis-ehei-metatrapei-to-sudagma/ |title=ÎÏÎµÎ¼Î¯Î± ÎµÏÎ¹ÎºÏÎ±ÏÎµÎ¯ Î±ÏÏÎ® ÏÎ·Î½ ÏÏÎ± ÏÏÎ·Î½ ÏÎ»Î±ÏÎµÎ¯Î± Î£ÏÎ½ÏÎ¬Î³Î¼Î±ÏÎ¿Ï |language=Greek |date=29 June 2011 |publisher=www.skai.gr |accessdate=29 June 2011}} Media also mention that the police used unnecessary violence against protesters. Officials from the [[Athens Metro]] also said that the police had fired [[tear gas]] inside the Syntagma Square metro station. Police also stormed [[Monastiraki]], as well as the streets around the [[Acropolis of Athens|Acropolis]], randomly hitting people eating at taverns and making extensive use of chemicals and stun grenades.{{cite web |url=http://tvxs.gr/news/%CE%B5%CE%BB%CE%BB%CE%AC%CE%B4%CE%B1/%CF%83%CF%85%CE%B3%CE%BA%CF%81%CE%BF%CF%8D%CF%83%CE%B5%CE%B9%CF%82-%CF%83%CE%B5-%CF%8C%CE%BB%CE%BF-%CF%84%CE%BF-%CE%BA%CE%AD%CE%BD%CF%84%CF%81%CE%BF-%CE%B1%CE%BD%CE%B5%CE%BE%CE%AD%CE%BB%CE%B5%CE%B3%CE%BA%CF%84%CE%B7-%CE%B7-%CE%B4%CF%81%CE%AC%CF%83%CE%B7-%CF%84%CE%B7%CF%82-%CE%B1%CF%83%CF%84%CF%85%CE%BD%CE%BF%CE%BC%CE%AF%CE%B1%CF%82 |title=Î£ÏÎ³ÎºÏÎ¿ÏÏÎµÎ¹Ï ÏÎµ ÏÎ»Î¿ ÏÎ¿ ÎºÎ­Î½ÏÏÎ¿-ÎÎ½ÎµÎ¾Î­Î»ÎµÎ³ÎºÏÎ· Î· Î´ÏÎ¬ÏÎ· ÏÎ·Ï Î±ÏÏÏÎ½Î¿Î¼Î¯Î±Ï |language=Greek |date=29 June 2011 |publisher=www.tvxs.gr |accessdate=1 July 2011}} Doctors at the infirmary set up at Othonos Square said the police had attacked them using stones and pieces of marble. Earlier, two members of the Teacher's Association were attacked by police and were injured, one of them on the head. Police also tried to deny access to the square to an ambulance attempting to transport heavily injured civilians to a hospital. A total of about 270 people were injured on 28 June alone, and over 500 visited the Syntagma Square metro station infirmary on 29 June. The Ministry of Health reported that 99 people were sent to hospitals on 29 June.{{cite web |url=http://www.agelioforos.gr/default.asp?pid=7&ct=1&artid=100099 |title="ÎÎ¿Î¼Î²Î±ÏÎ´Î¹ÏÎ¼Î­Î½Î¿ ÏÎ¿ÏÎ¯Î¿" ÏÎ¿ ÎºÎ­Î½ÏÏÎ¿ ÏÎ·Ï ÎÎ¸Î®Î½Î±Ï - 99 Î¬Î½Î¸ÏÏÏÎ¿Î¹ ÏÏÎ¿ Î½Î¿ÏÎ¿ÎºÎ¿Î¼ÎµÎ¯Î¿ |accessdate=29 June 2011 |language=Greek}} Following almost two days of violence in the streets in front of the Greek parliament, the Greek TV channel [[Alter Channel|Alter]] aired a video apparently showing members of the [[riot police]] cooperating with hooded youth.{{cite web |url=http://news.ert.gr/index.php/eidiseis/ellada/politiki/5857-2011-06-29-21-06-38.html |title=ÎÎÎÎ£: ÎÏÎµÏÎ½Î± Î³Î¹Î± ÏÎ¿ Î²Î¯Î½ÏÎµÎ¿ |accessdate=29 June 2011 |publisher=Hellenic Broadcasting Corporation |language=Greek}} The Minister for Citizen Protection, [[Christos Papoutsis]], ordered an immediate investigation in the claims{{cite web |url=http://www.minocp.gov.gr/index.php?option=ozo_content&perform=view&id=3723&Itemid=503&lang= |title=29-06-2011: ÎÎ½Î±ÎºÎ¿Î¯Î½ÏÏÎ· Î³Î¹Î± Î¬Î¼ÎµÏÎ· Î´Î¹ÎµÎ½Î­ÏÎ³ÎµÎ¹Î± Î­ÏÎµÏÎ½Î±Ï ÏÏÎµÏÎ¹ÎºÎ¬ Î¼Îµ Î²Î¯Î½ÏÎµÎ¿ ÏÎ¿Ï ÏÏÎ¿Î²Î»Î®Î¸Î·ÎºÎµ ÏÎ®Î¼ÎµÏÎ± (29-06-2011) ÏÎµ ÎÎµÎ½ÏÏÎ¹ÎºÏ ÎÎµÎ»ÏÎ¯Î¿ ÎÎ¹Î´Î®ÏÎµÏÎ½ ÏÎ¿Ï ÏÎ·Î»ÎµÎ¿ÏÏÎ¹ÎºÎ¿Ï ÏÏÎ±Î¸Î¼Î¿Ï ALTER |accessdate=29 June 2011 |publisher=Hellenic Republic Ministry for Citizen Protection |language=Greek}} according to which the police was aiding the hooded youth which vandalized Syntagma Square and the surrounding areas and later allowed them to move behind the police lines. The damage caused to Athens' historic city center is estimated to be over 500,000 [[euro]],{{cite web |url=http://www.skai.gr/news/greece/article/173739/evea-xepernoun-tis-pedakosies-hiliades-euro-oi-zimies-apo-ta-epeisodia-/ |title=ÎÎÎÎ: ÎÎµÏÎµÏÎ½Î¿ÏÎ½ ÏÎ¹Ï ÏÎµÎ½ÏÎ±ÎºÏÏÎ¹ÎµÏ ÏÎ¹Î»Î¹Î¬Î´ÎµÏ ÎµÏÏÏ Î¿Î¹ Î¶Î·Î¼Î¯ÎµÏ Î±ÏÏ ÏÎ± ÎµÏÎµÎ¹ÏÏÎ´Î¹Î± |accessdate=1 July |language=Greek}} as shop fronts were vandalized by hooded youth.{{cite web |url=http://www.skai.gr/player/TV/?MMID=216027 |title=Î Î»Î®Î³Î¼Î± Î³Î¹Î± ÏÎ·Î½ ÎÎ»Î»Î¬Î´Î± ÏÎ¿ Î²Î¿Î¼Î²Î±ÏÎ´Î¹ÏÎ¼Î­Î½Î¿ ÎºÎ­Î½ÏÏÎ¿ |accessdate=30 June 2011 |language=Greek}} Three of Greece's most famous hotels located on Syntagma Square were forced to evacuate their guests and personnel in view of the uncontrollable situation, something that the media say has not happened since the [[Dekemvriana|events of December 1944]], which started the [[Greek Civil War]]. Meanwhile in [[Thessaloniki]] a crowd of people had blocked a number of important political and religious figures from exiting the grounds of the [[Papafeio|Papafeio Orphanage]], including Minister of Health [[Andreas Loverdos]] and the metropolitan bishop of Thessaloniki, Anthimus.{{cite web |url=http://makthes.gr/news/reportage/76226/ |title=ÎÎ³Î±Î½Î±ÎºÏÎ¹ÏÎ¼Î­Î½Î¿ Î¼ÏÎ»ÏÎºÎ¿ ÏÏÎ¿ Î Î±ÏÎ¬ÏÎµÎ¹Î¿ |accessdate=29 June 2011 |language=Greek}} The crowds demanded that the [[Greek Orthodox Church]] help Greece in this time of crisis and accused the clergy of receiving oversized salaries. When protesters asked the metropolitan bishop how much his religious attire costs, he replied "not much, it's fake". They were forced to exit the grounds through the back door with the aid of the police, using police cars and taxis, while Anthimus left on foot. Despite the violent protests and use of tear gas by police to evacuate Syntagma Square the previous evening, peaceful protests continued on 30 June with thousands of people gathered in front of the Greek parliament.{{cite web |url=http://www.agelioforos.gr/default.asp?pid=7&ct=1&artid=100228 |title=ÎÏÎ¹ÏÏÏÎ­ÏÎ¿ÏÎ½ ÏÏÎ·Î½ Î Î»Î±ÏÎµÎ¯Î± Î£ÏÎ½ÏÎ¬Î³Î¼Î±ÏÎ¿Ï Î¿Î¹ ÎÎ³Î±Î½Î±ÎºÏÎ¹ÏÎ¼Î­Î½Î¿Î¹ Î³Î¹Î± Î½Î± ÎµÎ¼ÏÎ¿Î´Î¯ÏÎ¿ÏÎ½ ÏÎ·Î½ ÏÎ®ÏÎ¹ÏÎ· ÏÎ¿Ï Î²Î±ÏÎ¹ÎºÎ¿Ï ÎµÏÎ±ÏÎ¼Î¿ÏÏÎ¹ÎºÎ¿Ï Î½ÏÎ¼Î¿Ï |accessdate=30 June 2011 |language=Greek}} Demonstrations also took place in Greece's second city, [[Thessaloniki]].{{cite web |url=http://www.agelioforos.gr/default.asp?pid=7&ct=1&artid=100259 |title=ÎÎµÏÏÎ±Î»Î¿Î½Î¯ÎºÎ·: Î£Î®Î¼ÎµÏÎ± ÏÏÎ¹Ï 19:00 Î¿Î¹ ÎÎ³Î±Î½Î±ÎºÏÎ¹ÏÎ¼Î­Î½Î¿Î¹ ÏÏÎ¿ ÎÎµÏÎºÏ Î ÏÏÎ³Î¿ Î±Î½Î±ÏÏÎ³ÎºÏÎ¿ÏÎ¿ÏÎ½ÏÎ±Î¹ |accessdate=30 June 2011 |language=Greek}} [[File:20110630 Indignados Syntagma general mass Athens Greece.jpg|thumb|The People's Assembly in front of the parliament on 30 June.]] [[image:20110629 Moutza demonstrations Greek parliament Athens Greece.jpg|thumb|The [[moutza]], an insulting gesture in Greek culture, is extensively used in the protests.]] [[File:20110629 Riot Police throwing rocks to Indignados Athens Greece video from RealDemocracy.ogv|thumb|A police officer appears to pick an object off the ground and throws it, as a protester using a camera calls to him to put it down because he is being filmed. Others in the background chant for the police to leave the square.]] ====July==== Protests across the country continued in July, marking 5 weeks and 2 days of protest on 1 July. Despite the fact that the austerity measures had been passed, a large crowd, but smaller than on previous days, gathered in front of the Greek parliament to protest peacefully on 2 July.{{cite web |url=http://www.skai.gr/news/greece/article/173863/pistoi-sto-radevou-tous-oi-aganaktismenoi/ |title=Î Î¹ÏÏÎ¿Î¯ ÏÏÎ¿ ÏÎ±Î½ÏÎµÎ²Î¿Ï ÏÎ¿ÏÏ Î¿Î¹ "ÎÎ³Î±Î½Î±ÎºÏÎ¹ÏÎ¼Î­Î½Î¿Î¹" |accessdate=3 July 2011 |language=Greek}} ====August==== The sit-in at [[Thessaloniki]]'s [[White Tower]] Square held throughout July and early August, until the municipal police evacuated the square of all protesters that had camped inside on 7 August 2011. The police said that the protesters were in violation of various archaeological and environmental provisions, while also making 7 arrests. On 14 August 2011 the indignants at [[Heraklion]]'s Eleftherias Square agreed to leave the square peacefully,{{cite web |url=http://www.skai.gr/news/greece/article/177319/xilothike-kai-to-kioski-ton-aganaktismenon-tis-kritis-/ |title=ÎÎ·Î»ÏÎ¸Î·ÎºÎµ ÎºÎ±Î¹ ÏÎ¿ ÎºÎ¹ÏÏÎºÎ¹ ÏÏÎ½ "ÎÎ³Î±Î½Î±ÎºÏÎ¹ÏÎ¼Î­Î½ÏÎ½" ÏÎ·Ï ÎÏÎ®ÏÎ·Ï |accessdate=23 August 2011 |language=Greek}} following the intervention of a local prosecutor; the prosecutor had warned that unless the demonstrators evacuate the square force would be used like in Athens. Following the evacuation of the square by the indignants, police cleared the square of the kiosk that the demonstrators had set up. ====Political reactions==== In an interview for the Greek newspaper ''Ethnos'' on 29 May 2011, the vice-president of the [[Government of Greece|Greek government]], [[Theodoros Pangalos]], against whom various slogans had been shouted during the demonstrations, adopted an ironic stance towards the movement. He said that "the formation of a political movement, however much the people who follow the technological trends don't want to hear this, does not depend on how many 'likes' or 'dislikes' it gets on Facebook".{{cite web |url=http://www.ethnos.gr/article.asp?catid=22767&subid=2&pubid=63097052 |title=ÎÏÎ¹ÏÏÏÎ¿ÏÎ® ÏÏÎ· Î´ÏÎ±ÏÎ¼Î® Î¸Î­Î»Î¿ÏÎ½ Î¿Î¹ Î¼Î±ÏÏÎ±Î³Î¿ÏÎ¯ÏÎµÏ |language=Greek |date=29 May 2011 |publisher=www.ethnos.gr |accessdate=29 May 2011}}{{cite web |url=http://www.skai.gr/news/politics/article/170747/theodoros-pagalos-kata-aganaktismenon-/ |title=ÎÎµÏÎ´ÏÏÎ¿Ï Î Î¬Î³ÎºÎ±Î»Î¿Ï ÎºÎ±ÏÎ¬ "ÎÎ³Î±Î½Î±ÎºÏÎ¹ÏÎ¼Î­Î½ÏÎ½" |language=Greek |date=29 May 2011 |publisher=www.skai.gr |accessdate=29 May 2011}}{{cite web |url=http://www.protothema.gr/greece/article/?aid=124924 |title=ÎÏÎ´Î± ÏÏÎ½ ÏÎµÏÎ½Î¿Î»Î¿Î³Î¹ÏÎ½ Î¿Î¹ ÎÎ³Î±Î½Î±ÎºÏÎ¹ÏÎ¼Î­Î½Î¿Î¹... |language=Greek |date=29 May 2011 |publisher=www.protothema.gr |accessdate=29 May 2011}} He added that "movements without ideology and organization, that is to say movements based on anger, can only lead to either an ineffective release [of tension], which at the end of the day is of no interest to the political world, or pave the way for an undemocratic change of regime by organized minorities". In response, the demonstrations addressed many chants to the vice-president, like "the country is sinking, Theodore, lose some weight!" and other more vulgar ones. On 29 May, the spokesman of the Greek government, [[Giorgos Petalotis]], spoke out against Pangalos, saying that Pangalos should remember that when he took part in demonstrations against the dictatorship as a member of the [[Communist Party of Greece|Communist Party]] in 1973, "some people considered these demonstrations provocative".{{cite web |url=http://www.tanea.gr/default.asp?pid=2&ct=1&artId=4633196 |title=Î ÂµÎµÎ³Î¬Î»Î· Î³Î¹Î¿ÏÏÎ® ÏÎ·Ï Î´Î¹Î±ÂµÎ±ÏÏÏÏÎ¯Î±Ï |language=Greek |date=30 May 2011 |publisher=www.tanea.gr |accessdate=30 May 2011}} He furthermore added that not only does the Indignant Citizens Movement have a clear ideology (even if it is a "technology trend" as Pangalos described it), but that it also "reflects the real needs of the Greek society". He pointed out that "denial [of the system] and no proposals lead nowhere". On 1 June, the [[Prime Minister of Greece]], [[George Papandreou]], commented in regards to the Indignant Citizens Movement saying that "today protesters in Greece and the world are demonstrating against matters of national governance which are more weak than they used to be and, despite their inner weaknesses, are trapped by the global powers and the changes of a global system".{{cite web |url=http://www.skai.gr/news/politics/article/171063/sholio-papandreou-gia-aganaktismenous-polites/ |title=Î£ÏÏÎ»Î¹Î¿ Î Î±ÏÎ±Î½Î´ÏÎ­Î¿Ï Î³Î¹Î± "ÎÎ³Î±Î½Î±ÎºÏÎ¹ÏÎ¼Î­Î½Î¿ÏÏ ÏÎ¿Î»Î¯ÏÎµÏ" |language=Greek |date=1 June 2011 |publisher=www.skai.gr |accessdate=1 June 2011}} Following the blockade of the Parliament by angry citizens on 31 May, which prevented the MPs inside from exiting the building, and also after the angry reactions against the MPs when they were allowed to exit (such as the throwing of empty water bottles, fruit and other objects), the deputy Minister of Education said "I understand that the Indignant Citizens Movement is not a threat to democracy, but violence is, and I condemn it".{{cite web |url=http://www.skai.gr/news/greece/article/171043/adidraseis-gia-tin-poliorkia-tis-voulis-apo-aganaktismenous-/ |title=ÎÎ½ÏÎ¹Î´ÏÎ¬ÏÎµÎ¹Ï Î³Î¹Î± ÏÎ·Î½ "ÏÎ¿Î»Î¹Î¿ÏÎºÎ¯Î±" ÏÎ·Ï ÎÎ¿ÏÎ»Î®Ï Î±ÏÏ "ÎÎ³Î±Î½Î±ÎºÏÎ¹ÏÎ¼Î­Î½Î¿ÏÏ" |language=Greek |date=1 June 2011 |publisher=www.skai.gr |accessdate=1 June 2011}} She added that "in a democracy, violence should be prevented and not tolerated" and that "the majority of the MPs in parliament are young; they should receive the same treatment as old MPs". The deputy Minister of Foreign Affairs commented that "I can accept tougher questioning and criticism, but not the leveling of our political system. Democracy can give [a] solution. The flattening of our democracy can only lead to a slippery road. The majority of the Greek people can be angry, but not under these circumstances". {{external media|video1={{YouTube|YkkVuycWmGk|Video of the Athens protets on 25 May}}|video2={{YouTube|2gwF8J2N2BM|The protests of Thessaloniki on 25 May}}|video3={{YouTube|jPSEN1ZQimA|The protests of Athens on 29 May}}|video4={{YouTube|S20_JuaX8gg|Video of police brutality on 29 June, destroying tents and hitting civilians}}|video5={{YouTube|p5FARBm7k48|Video of police hitting and gassing people in a grocery store near Syntagma on 29 June}}|video6={{YouTube|2xR_ME-XYZM|Video of police throwing tear gas inside a Metro station packed with people}}}} [[Member of the European Parliament|European Parliament MP]] Theodoros Skylakakis, who is aligned with the newly-founded [[Democratic Alliance (Greece)|Democratic Alliance]] party, said that "these people need to get a sense of political ideology and move to a deeper revelation: from what they don't like, to what they like",{{cite web |url=http://www.skai.gr/news/politics/article/170750/skulakakis-ginetai-tsakomos-eno-erhetai-to-tsounami/ |title=Î£ÎºÏÎ»Î±ÎºÎ¬ÎºÎ·Ï: ÎÎ¯Î½ÎµÏÎ±Î¹ ÏÏÎ±ÎºÏÎ¼ÏÏ ÎµÎ½Ï Î­ÏÏÎµÏÎ±Î¹ ÏÎ¿ ÏÏÎ¿ÏÎ½Î¬Î¼Î¹ |language=Greek |date=29 May 2011 |publisher=www.skai.gr |accessdate=29 May 2011}} implying that a non-political movement will be ineffective and without results. [[Alexis Tsipras]], leader of the [[Synaspismos]] radical left party and the first party leader to comment on the demonstrations, said that "no one has the right to make the people [silent], or tell them that they have no say in their country's future by means of a referendum".{{cite web |url=http://www.enet.gr/?i=news.el.politikh&id=279502 |title=Î¤ÏÎ­Î¼Î¿ÏÎ½ ÏÎ·Î½ ÎºÎ¿Î¹Î½ÏÎ½Î¹ÎºÎ® Î±Î½Î±ÏÎ±ÏÎ±ÏÎ® ÏÏÎ·Î½ ÎÏÏÏÏÎ· |language=Greek |date=29 May 2011 |publisher=www.enet.gr |accessdate=29 May 2011}} He added that the [[Left (politics)|Left]] should be supportive of the demonstrations and that "things are turning at a fast pace, and the people are waking up". The [[Mayor of Athens]] said on 30 May that the protest was a "healthy and sound demonstration", but when a motion was put forth at the municipal council to declare the municipality's support for the demonstrations, the mayor said that he felt "it is not appropriate to express our sympathy". In an interview with a Greek newspaper on 1 June 2011, the Spanish [[Democracia real Ya|Democracia Real YA!]] movement, which organized the [[2011 Spanish Protests]] and sparked the Greek protests, said that its members support the Greek demonstrations and that "this is only the beginning".{{cite web |url=http://www.protothema.gr/world/article/?aid=125534 |title=H "Î ÏÎ±Î³Î¼Î±ÏÎ¹ÎºÎ® ÎÎ·Î¼Î¿ÎºÏÎ±ÏÎ¯Î± Î¤ÏÏÎ±" ÎºÎ±Î»ÎµÎ¯ ÏÎ¿ÏÏ ÎÎ»Î»Î·Î½ÎµÏ Î½Î± Î¾ÎµÏÎ·ÎºÏÎ¸Î¿ÏÎ½! |language=Greek |date=1 June 2011 |publisher=www.protothema.gr |accessdate=1 June 2011}} On 2 June 2011, 16 parliament members of PASOK publicly demanded of [[George Papandreou]] that the parliament make a full report of country's current financial situation.{{cite web |url=http://www.tovima.gr/politics/article/?aid=404346 |title=ÎÎ®Î¼Î·ÏÏÎ± ÎÏÎ¿ÏÏÏÎ¬Î»Î»Î·: Î Î±Î£Î¿Î: ÎÎµ ÎµÏÎ¹ÏÏÎ¿Î»Î® ÏÎ¿ÏÏ 16 Î²Î¿ÏÎ»ÎµÏÏÎ­Ï Î¶Î·ÏÎ¿ÏÎ½ Î¬Î¼ÎµÏÎ· ÏÏÎ³ÎºÎ»Î·ÏÎ· ÏÏÎ½ Î¿ÏÎ³Î¬Î½ÏÎ½ ÏÎ¿Ï ÎºÏÎ¼Î¼Î±ÏÎ¿Ï |language=Greek |date=2 June 2011 |publisher=www.tovima.gr |accessdate=2 June 2011}} This was caused by the forthcoming second memoradum voting, which [[George Papandreou]] characterised as "urgent". In the early hours of 22 June 2011, George Papandreou and his government narrowly survived a [[vote of confidence]] in the [[Greek parliament]], with 155 of the 300 seats voting in favor.{{cite news|title=Greek government survives confidence vote |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-13869428 |publisher=www.bbc.co.uk |accessdate=21 June 2011 |date=21 June 2011}} On 28 June 2011, amid violent protests in the square outside parliament, the [[Hellenic Parliament]] voted in favor of passing a new set of [[austerity measures]] with a marginal majority of 155 seats in the 300-seat parliament.{{cite web |url=http://www.skai.gr/news/politics/article/173650/efarmostikos-psifisthike-epi-tis-arhis-apo-155-vouleutes/ |title=ÎÏÎ±ÏÎ¼Î¿ÏÏÎ¹ÎºÏÏ: Î¨Î·ÏÎ¯ÏÎ¸Î·ÎºÎµ ÎµÏÎ¯ ÏÎ·Ï Î±ÏÏÎ®Ï Î±ÏÏ 155 Î²Î¿ÏÎ»ÎµÏÏÎ­Ï |language=Greek |date=30 June 2011 |publisher=www.skai.gr |accessdate=3 July 2011}} The measures themselves had attracted much criticism both from the Greek public and within the country's political scene. Between June and July 2011, [[PASOK]] went from an 156-seat majority to a 154-seat one, while [[Nea Dimokratia|New Democracy]] also lost one seat. The allegations of [[police brutality]] by Greek and foreign media as well as [[Amnesty International]] sparked heated debate in the [[Hellenic Parliament]], with all parties in the house asking the government for explanations, including MPs of the ruling [[PASOK]] party.{{cite web |url=http://www.skai.gr/news/politics/article/173639/anoixe-o-askos-tou-aiolou-sti-vouli-exaitias-ton-epeisodion/ |title=ÎÎ½Î¿Î¹Î¾Îµ Î¿ Î±ÏÎºÏÏ ÏÎ¿Ï ÎÎ¹ÏÎ»Î¿Ï ÏÏÎ· ÎÎ¿ÏÎ»Î® ÎµÎ¾Î±Î¹ÏÎ¯Î±Ï ÏÏÎ½ ÎµÏÎµÎ¹ÏÎ¿Î´Î¯ÏÎ½ |language=Greek |date=30 June 2011 |publisher=www.skai.gr |accessdate=3 July 2011}} The leader of the opposition, [[Antonis Samaras]], characterized the situation as almost that of a "parastate", while [[George Karatzaferis]] of the [[Popular Orthodox Rally]] accused the government of "not being able to control 200 thugs in central Athens". The radical left party [[SYRIZA]] accused the government of "abolishing the very principles of democracy" and filed a complaint against the government for "cheering while at the same time outside the building tear gas was being overly used". Members of the parliamentary group of PASOK characterized the actions of the police as "barbaric" [[Christos Papoutsis]], the [[Minister for Citizen Protection]], denied all accusations claiming that "it's the police that operates, not the government". Regarding the video in which police are allegedly helping hooded youth, he said that the people in the video are not police; the Athens Prosecutor accepted the demands for an investigation into the matter. On the matter of the attack on the [[Syntagma station|Sytagma Square metro station]] using tear gas by police, the minister said that "people with health issues were transported to hospitals and the others left inside were wearing gas masks more expensive than the ones used by police". [[Giannis Ragousis]], Minister for Transport, asked for a disciplinary measure to punish those responsible. The [[European Commission]] stated that any use of violence is sad and unacceptable. Additionally, the Greek government has pledged to amend the constitution as a result of the protests.{{cite web|title=ÎÎ·Î¼Î¿ÏÎ®ÏÎ¹ÏÎ¼Î± ÏÏÎ¹Î½ Î±ÏÏ ÏÎ·Î½ Î±Î½Î±Î¸ÎµÏÏÎ·ÏÎ· |url=http://news.kathimerini.gr/4dcgi/_w_articles_politics_1_21/06/2011_446517 |publisher=www.kathimerini.gr |accessdate=4 July 2011}} Among the most important aspects of the constitutional reform will be the change of the functions of the Greek political system.{{cite web|title=ÎÎ½Î·Î¼Î­ÏÏÏÎ· Î£ÏÎ½ÏÎ±ÎºÏÏÎ½ 20.06.2011 |url=http://government.gov.gr/2011/06/20/15769/ |publisher=www.government.gov.gr |accessdate=4 July 2011}} The Greek government has said it will open up the discussion on constitutional amendment in September, both to the public and the media. Other media have pointed out that this could not be legal before 2013 because the [[Greek constitutional amendment of 2008|constitutional amendment of 2008]] forbids any other changes to the constitution prior to 2013. ====Public perception and media coverage==== In a survey published in June 2011 by Public Issue on behalf of the Greek TV channel [[Skai TV|Skai]], 98% of people asked said they were informed about the protests.{{cite web |url=http://www.skai.gr/files/1/PDF/aganaktismenoi.pdf |title=Î¤Î¿ ÎÎ¯Î½Î·Î¼Î± ÏÏÎ½ ÎÎ³Î±Î½Î±ÎºÏÎ¹ÏÎ¼Î­Î½ÏÎ½ Î Î¿Î»Î¹ÏÏÎ½ |language=Greek |date=June 2011 |publisher=www.skai.gr |accessdate=3 July 2011}} Additionally, 95% of people asked said they had positive impressions about the movement. When asked about their overall opinion of the movement, 86% replied either positive (76%) or probably positive (10%) while 6% replied negative, with an additional 2% as probably negative. 35% of the people asked said they had participated in at least one protest. When asked about their opinion in regards to the media coverage of the events, 53% replied negative and 39% positive. 51% thought the demonstrations are a "very important" event, while 34% felt it was "quite important", with 12% replying they viewed it as either not very important or not important at all. When asked if they believe that the protests may have been politically orchestrated by a political power within the country, 80% replied no and 16% yes. Finally, 52% believed that the protests will bring results, while 39% believed they will not. Demonstrations were scheduled to continue for "as long as it takes". These demonstrations were the largest event to be organized over the internet in Greece.{{cite web |url=http://www.ert.gr/index.php/eidiseis/ellada/38-koinonia/6496-2011-05-26-14-42-50.html |title=''ÎÎ³Î±Î½Î±ÎºÏÎ¹ÏÎ¼Î­Î½Î¿Î¹'' Î¾Î±Î½Î¬ ("Outraged" again) |language=Greek |date=26 May 2011 |publisher=www.news.ert.gr |accessdate=26 May 2011}} It is of note that, with the exception of [[Skai TV]], [[Star Channel]] and Zougla Radio, which provided live coverage of the demonstrations in [[Athens]], media coverage of these events was relatively poor in the first weeks. It is indicative that major Greek TV channel [[Mega Channel|Mega]] was forced to termporarily deactivate its Facebook page as thousands of people left negative and derogatory comments on the page because the channel did not cover the events of 29 May.{{cite web |url=http://www.facebook.com/tvmega/posts/211454365562228 |title=Mega Tv's Profile |date=30 May 2011 |publisher=www.facebook.com |accessdate=30 May 2011}} The demonstrations did catch the attention of the [[International Monetary Fund]], and the spokesman of the organization expressed "understanding" for the demonstrators.{{cite web |url=http://www.enet.gr/?i=news.el.ellada&id=278949 |title=ÎÎ±ÏÎ±Î½Î¿ÎµÎ¯ ÏÎ¿ÏÏ "ÎÎ³Î±Î½Î±ÎºÏÎ¹ÏÎ¼Î­Î½Î¿ÏÏ" ÏÎ·Ï ÎÎ»Î»Î¬Î´Î±Ï ÏÎ¿ ÎÎÎ¤ |date=27 May 2011 |publisher=www.enet.gr |accessdate=27 May 2011}}{{cite web |url=http://www.imf.org/external/np/tr/2011/tr052611.htm |title=Transcript of a Press Briefing by Caroline Atkinson, Director, External Relations Department, International Monetary Fund |date=26 May 2011 |publisher=www.imf.org |accessdate=27 May 2011}} Additionally, the demonstrations have also been featured in [[Euronews]], [[El Pais]], El Economista and [[CNN]].{{cite web |url=http://www.euronews.net/2011/05/25/outraged-greek-youth-follow-spanish-example/ |title=Outraged Greek youth follow Spanish example |date=25 May 2011 |publisher=www.euronews.eu |accessdate=28 May 2011}}{{cite web |url=http://politica.elpais.com/politica/2011/05/25/actualidad/1306346980_133998.html |title=Miles de griegos protestan contra los recortes frente al Parlamento de Atenas |language=Spanish |date=25 May 2011 |publisher=www.politica.elpais.com |accessdate=28 May 2011}}{{cite web |url=http://www.eleconomista.es/mercados-cotizaciones/noticias/3103568/05/11/Miles-de-indignados-griegos-toman-la-plaza-Sintagma-en-contra-de-recortes.html |title=Miles de "indignados" griegos toman la plaza Sintagma en contra de recortes |language=Spanish |date=25 May 2011 |publisher=www.eleconomista.es |accessdate=28 May 2011}} [[Mikis Theodorakis]], prominent Greek songwriter and political activist, especially during the years of the dictatorship (1967â1974), also expressed his support for the movement in an open letter addressed to the demonstrators.{{cite web |url=http://www.enet.gr/?i=news.el.politikh&id=279626 |title=Î ÎÎ¯ÎºÎ·Ï ÏÏÎ­Î»Î½ÎµÎ¹ Î³ÏÎ¬Î¼Î¼Î± ÏÏÎ¹Ï Î Î»Î±ÏÎµÎ¯ÎµÏ |language=Greek |date=28 May 2011 |publisher=www.enet.gr |accessdate=28 May 2011}} Famous Greek singer Giannis Kotsiras also expressed his open support for the initiative. Some members of the Greek clergy have also expressed their open support for the demonstrations, notably bishops Anthimus of Thessaloniki and Ambrosius of [[Kalavryta]].{{cite web |url=http://www.skai.gr/news/greece/article/170955/amvrosios-na-ginoume-oloi-aganaktismenoi-polites/ |title=ÎÎ¼Î²ÏÏÏÎ¹Î¿Ï: "ÎÎ± Î³Î¯Î½Î¿ÏÎ¼Îµ ÏÎ»Î¿Î¹ "Î±Î³Î±Î½Î±ÎºÏÎ¹ÏÎ¼Î­Î½Î¿Î¹ ÏÎ¿Î»Î¯ÏÎµÏ"" |language=Greek |date=31 May 2011 |publisher=www.skai.gr |accessdate=31 May 2011}} ====Gallery====
image:Syntagma Square 'indignados'.png|Athens (25 May) image:Aganaktismenoi Larissas 30 May 2011.JPG|[[Larissa]] (30 May) image:Indignados,Patras 5.JPG|[[Patras]] (5 June) image:Aganaktismenoi Syndagma June 29 2011.JPG|Police barricade image:20110630 Syntagma Square after Demonstrations of Indignados Athens Greece 2.jpg|Destruction of 29 June (Athens)
===Other protests in 2011=== ====August==== On 23 August 2011, there was a demonstration by workers in the tourism sector. The Pan-Worker's Front staged a [[sit-in]] at some of Athens' most famous hotels on [[Syntagma Square]],{{cite web |url=http://www.skai.gr/news/greece/article/177968/pame-bloko-sta-xenodoheia-tis-plateias-sudagmatos/ |title=ÎÎ¹ÎºÎ·ÏÎ¹Î¬Î´Î·Ï Î³Î¹Î± ÏÎ± Î¼ÏÎ»ÏÎºÎ± ÏÎµ Î¾ÎµÎ½Î¿Î´Î¿ÏÎµÎ¯Î±: ÎÏÏÎ·ÏÎ¬ ÏÎ±Î¹Î½ÏÎ¼ÎµÎ½Î± ÏÏÎ¿Î½ ÏÎ¿ÏÏÎ¹ÏÎ¼Ï |language=Greek |date=23 August 2011 |publisher=www.skai.gr |accessdate=23 August 2011}}{{cite web |url=http://www.skai.gr/news/greece/article/177987/diamarturia-ergazomenon-ston-tourismo-gia-ta-varea-kai-anthugieina-/ |title=Î£ÏÎ½ÎµÏÎ¯Î¶ÎµÏÎ±Î¹ Î· Î´Î¹Î±Î¼Î±ÏÏÏÏÎ¯Î± ÎµÏÎ³Î±Î¶Î¿Î¼Î­Î½ÏÎ½ ÏÏÎ¿Î½ ÏÎ¿ÏÏÎ¹ÏÎ¼Ï Î³Î¹Î± ÏÎ± Î²Î±ÏÎ­Î± ÎºÎ±Î¹ Î±Î½Î¸ÏÎ³Î¹ÎµÎ¹Î½Î¬ |language=Greek |date=23 August 2011 |publisher=www.skai.gr |accessdate=23 August 2011}} as well as the iconic Electra Palace Hotel in [[Thessaloniki]]'s [[Aristotelous Square]]. Meanwhile the Federation of Tourism Workers held a 24-hour [[strike action|strike]] and a demonstration in a central square of Athens. The Federation also said that they would hold another 24-hour strike, but did not define a date for it. The sit-in at various hotels was met with criticism from government officials as well as various [[labor unions]] involved in the tourism sector. ====September==== In early September 2011, as new measures were announced by the Minister for Finance on 6 September,{{cite web |url=http://www.enet.gr/?i=news.el.oikonomia&id=307512 |title=Î ÎºÏÎ²Î­ÏÎ½Î·ÏÎ· Î±ÏÎ¿ÏÎ¬ÏÎ¹ÏÎµ Ï,ÏÎ¹ Î´Î¹Î­ÏÎ±Î¾Îµ Î· ÏÏÏÎ¹ÎºÎ± |language=Greek |date=6 September 2011 |publisher=www.enet.gr |accessdate=7 September 2011}} various unions of the country's public sector announced they would go on strike.{{cite web |url=http://www.skai.gr/news/greece/article/179345/baraz-kinitopoiiseon-kata-ton-kuvernitikon-apofaseon/ |title=ÎÏÎ±ÏÎ¬Î¶ ÎºÎ¹Î½Î·ÏÎ¿ÏÎ¿Î¹Î®ÏÎµÏÎ½ ÎºÎ±ÏÎ¬ ÏÏÎ½ ÎºÏÎ²ÎµÏÎ½Î·ÏÎ¹ÎºÏÎ½ Î±ÏÎ¿ÏÎ¬ÏÎµÏÎ½ |language=Greek |date=7 September 2011 |publisher=www.skai.gr |accessdate=7 September 2011}}{{cite web |url=http://www.tanea.gr/ellada/article/?aid=4655229 |title=ÎÏÎµÏÎ³Î¹Î±ÎºÏÏ "ÏÏÏÎµÏÏÏ" ÏÏÎ· ÏÏÏÎ± Î¼ÎµÏÎ¬ ÏÎ± Î¼Î­ÏÏÎ± ÏÎ·Ï ÎºÏÎ²Î­ÏÎ½Î·ÏÎ·Ï |language=Greek |date=7 September 2011 |publisher=www.tanea.gr |accessdate=7 September 2011}} These include teachers, doctors, taxi drivers, customs officials and tax collectors,{{cite web |url=http://www.enet.gr/?i=news.el.oikonomia&id=307803 |title=ÎÏÎµÏÎ³Î¿ÏÎ½ ÎÎµÏÏÎ­ÏÎ± ÎºÎ±Î¹ Î¤ÏÎ¯ÏÎ· ÎµÏÎ¿ÏÎ¹Î±ÎºÎ¿Î¯ ÎºÎ±Î¹ ÏÎµÎ»ÏÎ½ÎµÎ¹Î±ÎºÎ¿Î¯ |language=Greek |date=7 September 2011 |publisher=www.enet.gr |accessdate=7 September 2011}} as well as [[waste collector]]s working for the municipality of [[Athens]]. Additionally, the [[air traffic controller]]'s union announced that, in the interest of serving the public, air traffic controllers would not go on strike but would refuse to work overtime.{{cite web |url=http://www.enet.gr/?i=news.el.ellada&id=307814 |title=ÎÎµ Î»ÎµÏÎºÎ® Î±ÏÎµÏÎ³Î¯Î± Î±ÏÎµÎ¹Î»Î¿ÏÎ½ Î¿Î¹ ÎµÎ»ÎµÎ³ÎºÏÎ­Ï ÎµÎ½Î±Î­ÏÎ¹Î±Ï ÎºÏÎºÎ»Î¿ÏÎ¿ÏÎ¯Î±Ï |language=Greek |date=7 September 2011 |publisher=www.enet.gr |accessdate=7 September 2011}} Workers at the Athens Urban Transport Organization (which includes the [[Athens Metro]]) are considering going on strike as well. ====October==== On October 5, 2011, there was a general strike.{{cite web |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-15177457 |title=Greece strike: Police and protesters clash in Athens |date=5 October 2011 |publisher=www.bbc.co.uk }} During the demonstrations police clashed with youth and made 10 arrests.{{cite web |url=http://www.skai.gr/news/greece/article/182418/ennea-sullipseis-kata-ta-epeisodia-stin-athina/ |title=ÎÎ­ÎºÎ± ÏÏÎ»Î»Î®ÏÎµÎ¹Ï ÎºÎ±ÏÎ¬ ÏÎ± ÎµÏÎµÎ¹ÏÏÎ´Î¹Î± ÏÏÎ·Î½ ÎÎ¸Î®Î½Î± |date=5 October 2011 |publisher=www.skai.gr}} Police are also investigating claims by journalists that they were assaulted by police officers. The police officer who assaulted the journalist was arrested, but then released on 6 October until conclusive evidence is found.{{cite web |url=http://www.skai.gr/news/greece/article/182533/eleutheros-me-edoli-eisaggelea-afethike-o-astunomikos-pou-htupise-ti-fotoreporter/ |title=ÎÎ»ÎµÏÎ¸ÎµÏÎ¿Ï Î¼Îµ ÎµÎ½ÏÎ¿Î»Î® ÎµÎ¹ÏÎ±Î³Î³ÎµÎ»Î­Î± Î±ÏÎ­Î¸Î·ÎºÎµ Î¿ Î±ÏÏÏÎ½Î¿Î¼Î¹ÎºÏÏ ÏÎ¿Ï ÏÏÏÏÎ·ÏÎµ ÏÎ· ÏÏÏÎ¿ÏÎµÏÏÏÏÎµÏ |date=5 October 2011 |publisher=www.skai.gr}} There were demonstrations in coordination with the [[Occupy Wall Street]] movement on [[15 October 2011 global protests|October 15]]. Only 7,000 demonstrators, according to estimates by local media, gathered on Syntagma square in a peaceful demonstration.{{cite web |url=http://greece.greekreporter.com/2011/10/15/greek-demonstrators-join-global-day-of-rage/ |title=Greek Demonstrators Join Global "Day of Rage" |date=15 October 2011 |publisher=www.greece.greekreporter.com}} Further protests and strikes were organized for October 19 and October 20. The strikes in fact began on 17 October, when the seaman's union walked off the job for 48 hours,{{cite web |url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/10/17/us-greece-strikes-idUSTRE79F2XD20111017 |title=Greece heads for standstill before austerity vote |date=17 October 2011 |publisher=www.reuters.com}} shutting down the ferry services between the islands. Customs officials who clear fuel refinery deliveries also held a 24-hour strike that day. The shortage of fuel and goods in the Greek islands due to the strike of ferry and fuel services has already began to manifest itself.{{cite web |url=http://www.skai.gr/news/greece/article/184114/xemenoun-ta-nisia-apo-trofima-venzini-/?utm_source=rss_news_greece&utm_campaign=skai200905190000&utm_medium=rss |title=ÎÎµÎ¼Î­Î½Î¿ÏÎ½ ÏÎ± Î½Î·ÏÎ¹Î¬ Î±ÏÏ ÏÏÏÏÎ¹Î¼Î± - Î²ÎµÎ½Î¶Î¯Î½Î· |accessdate=23 October 2011 |publisher=www.skai.gr}} On the second day of the protests, reported to be the largest in decades, a riot ensued and one person died.http://www.businessweek.com/ap/financialnews/D9QG3LKG2.htm On 28 October (a national holiday [[Ochi Day|in Greece]]), protests occurred nationwide. In [[Thessaloniki]], where a national military parade is held annually, protesters prevented the parade from officially taking place (the first time this occurred since the parade was first held in 1941) and shouted slogans against [[Karolos Papoulias]],{{cite web |url=http://www.skai.gr/news/greece/article/184631/akurothike-i-parelasi-sti-thessaloniki-apohorise-o-k-papoulias/ |title=ÎÎºÏÏÏÎ¸Î·ÎºÎµ Î· ÏÎ±ÏÎ­Î»Î±ÏÎ· ÏÏÎ· ÎÎµÏÏÎ±Î»Î¿Î½Î¯ÎºÎ· - ÎÏÎ¿ÏÏÏÎ·ÏÎµ Î¿ÏÎ³Î¹ÏÎ¼Î­Î½Î¿Ï Î¿ Î. Î Î±ÏÎ¿ÏÎ»Î¹Î±Ï |trans_title=Parade in Thessaloniki cancelled - Mr. Papoulias departed outraged |accessdate=28 October 2011 |publisher=www.skai.gr}} the [[President of Greece]], who was forced to leave. However, the civilian part of the parade along with the conscriptees marched as planned, acclaimed by the crowd.{{cite web |url=http://www.real.gr/DefaultArthro.aspx?page=arthro&id=101648&catID=1/ |title=ÎÎ±ÏÎ±Î¹ÏÎ¸Î·ÎºÎµ Î· ÏÏÏÎ±ÏÎ¹ÏÏÎ¹ÎºÎ® ÏÎ±ÏÎ­Î»Î±ÏÎ· ÏÎ·Ï ÎÎµÏÏÎ±Î»Î¿Î½Î¯ÎºÎ·Ï |trans_title=The military parade in Thessaloniki was cancelled |accessdate=28 October 2011 |publisher=www.real.gr}} In Athens, during the annual student parade, several schools turned their heads away from the officials present (which included [[Anna Diamantopoulou]], the Minister of Education),{{cite web |url=http://www.skai.gr/news/greece/article/184632/teatameno-klima-stin-mathitiki-parelasi-sto-sudagma/ |title=ÎÎµ Î¼Î±ÏÏÎµÏ ÎºÎ¿ÏÎ´Î­Î»ÎµÏ Î¼Î±Î¸Î·ÏÎ­Ï ÎºÎ±Î¹ Î¼ÏÎ¬Î½ÏÎ± ÏÎ¿Ï ÎÎ®Î¼Î¿Ï ÎÎ¸Î·Î½Î±Î¯ÏÎ½ ÏÏÎ¿ Î£ÏÎ½ÏÎ±Î³Î¼Î± |trans_title=Band of Athens Municipality and students wearing black ribbons at Syntagma Square |accessdate=28 October 2011 |publisher=www.skai.gr}} while of the members of the band of the Municipality of Athens attached black ribbons to their instruments. Additionally, a crowd of people had gathered in front of Hotel Grand Bretagne in central Athens (close to the VIP stand) and shouted slogans against the economic crisis. In [[Heraklion]] protesters threw eggs at the officials,{{cite web |url=http://www.skai.gr/news/greece/article/184633/kriti-auga-kata-episimon-/ |title=ÎÏÎ³Î¬ ÎºÎ±ÏÎ¬ ÎµÏÎ¹ÏÎ®Î¼ÏÎ½ ÏÎµ ÎÏÎ®ÏÎ· ÎºÎ±Î¹ Î±ÏÎ¿Î´Î¿ÎºÎ¹Î¼Î±ÏÎ¯ÎµÏ ÏÏÎ·Î½ Î Î¬ÏÏÎ± |trans_title=Eggs against officials in Crete and heckling in Patras |accessdate=28 October 2011 |publisher=www.skai.gr}} while in [[Patras]] protesters occupied the street where the scheduled student parade was to take place and shouted slogans agains the officials present (which included the Minister for Defence). Heckling of politicians occurred in many other cities across the country, including [[Trikala]], [[Volos]], [[Corfu]], [[Serres]], [[Veroia]], [[Tripoli (Greece)|Tripoli]] and [[Rhodes]].{{cite web |url=http://www.enet.gr/?i=news.el.ellada&id=321809 |title=Î Î±ÏÎ­Î»Î±ÏÎ· Î»Î±ÏÎºÎ®Ï Î¿ÏÎ³Î®Ï, ÎºÎ±ÏÎ¬ ÏÎ¿Ï ÏÏÎµÎ¿ÎºÎ¿ÏÎ·Î¼Î­Î½Î¿Ï ÏÎ¿Î»Î¹ÏÎ¹ÎºÎ¿Ï ÏÏÏÏÎ®Î¼Î±ÏÎ¿Ï
